On top of that, it has a bad habit of not registering rapid-fire pistol shots - perhaps a productive of my low-spec computer, however.Tomb Raider: Anniversary isn't a perfect game, but it is a fantastic game. If you're looking for a platformer with level design that stands the test of time and has some pleasing fluid gameplay to boot, then Tomb Raider: Anniversary should be right up your alley.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												5 out of 10This game gets a thumbs up with an if.  A BIG IF.  If you have the patience of Buddha then you can consider playing this game.  Know that it will torment you to the point where you want to smash your pc to pieces.  This game could be used as a means of punishing criminals. This is a reboot of the first Tomb Raider, a true classic and a game I loved.  Obviously the graphics is much better.  The level layout and controls have also been updated. The good:1. This is a true Tomb Raider game where it is mostly about Lara vs the environment.  It's not like Tomb Raider 2013 where there is an enemy or ten behind every corner. 2. I am glad the levels have been redesigned.  It sort of works.  Maybe it is just memory but they do feel dumbed down a bit though.  3. Even though this game is some 7 years old the scenery looks really great.  Character models and textures are nothing like modern games though. 4. You can take selfies of Lara as she roams ancient locations. The Bad: 5. The controls.  The original Tomb Raider was genius with its minimalist controls.  The reboot does not emulate it unfortunately.  On the original you could jump forward, to one side, backwards and to the other side an infinite number of times and Lara would end up exactly where she started.  Forget about it with the reboot.  The introduction of the mouse changed a lot. 6. Related to the above point, in the original you could control Lara very accurately.  She'd jump when you press jump; do front and back somersaults at will; jump at exactly the end of ledge or slide.  No more.  You get used to ledges but slides are atrocious. 7. How difficult could it have been to keep an autosave that the player can load at will?  You have to manually save after each check point.  No matter where you save, you reload at the last checkpoint. The ugly: 8. The two major additions the game, the grapple and timed dodge and shoot are the worst though.  Even after completing the game I have no confidence that I can get any of these two right at will.  Lara's responses seems very random to the input you give.  The shoot dodge works ok if you face only one enemy but when there are more - good luck.  The grapple though is what really gets me. 9. It feels like the game developers thought how they can make the world a little worse place to live?  Hehehe... lets make a really nice game with a bug witch acts up randomly at critical times.  The grapple is perfect for this.  When the player press jump to side we make Lara jump perpendicular and vice versa but remember only at some random critical times. 10. The make matters worse the checkpoints seems to come just after a long sequence of activities punctuated with one of these random grapples at the end.  Possibly half of my game time was doing bits over and over and over again until Lara did what I instructed. 11. Lara's Mansion introduction mission.  I owned this game for many years but only now played it.  Each time I would start with the introduction and then stop playing because it would irritate the living daylights out of me. I recommend this game with big reservations.  After playing I think that if the developers took the original and only gave it a new coat the game would have been infinitely better. This game is 95% good and 5% bad.  A pity the 5% bad takes up 50% of your playtime.  Really consider playing the original in stead.

content:
Posted: March 26, 2016
												Hello people, so I see your looking at one of the many great Tomb Raider games! I, myself, have all the games and I am working on completing all of them. This one is a remake of the first one with alittle bit extra added, and I am glad they remade Lara because the first one was godly. Of course though, to all games there are pros and most definitly cons so lets jump right into that! PROS!!! The game has beautiful senery that you can get lost in which is a lovely touch. Going from a ruined city to a thick rain forest is amazing.The fighting in the game is simple and fun, having a feature to slow down time and jump over enemies and such is also an amazing aspect.The puzzles in this game are fantastic, from little contraptions to huge doors that have to be opened quickly and as you run for the door breathing hard.The climbing is great, you have a grappling hook, and of course your hands to go around the amazing senery and get to new places that could possibly hold relics and such. CONS!!! The AI can be a bit derpy, but I only ran into that maybe 1 or twice.This isnt really a con, but at some points I got confused where to go and fell and died alot at the same part.The game has some crazy plot twist that are hard to follow if your one of those people who skip every cutscene.So if I were to give with from a 0 to a 10 I'd give it a definite 9 because I love the Tomb Raider games and I love the art style to them. Of course the game has its bugs and issues like sometimes you might now be able to grapple and you fall, but it is always fun and never get bored or tired. Its also pretty fun to speed through and collect all the costumes.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 19, 2016
												I grew up on Tomb Raider, it was probably one of the first games I ever actually played from start to finish. Back in 2006 when this game came out I did not hesitate to get it, the same happened ten years later when it went on sale.I was a bit cautious at first as I couldn't exactly remember what the game was like on the PS2 and what with all the negative reviews regarding camera angles and controls, I was scared this was going to be a terrible port.Having completed the game, story wise that is, I can say that, yes whilst the camera angles are sometimes terrible, I can't deny that I've actually had SO much fun with this game.Pros: The Soundtrack is actually in this oneCombat is fast and tense in some cases, especially on smaller platforms in later levelsLong but not at all tedious puzzlesAtmosphere is pretty damn good for a game that's roughly a decade oldGraphics ain't too bad either, few bits of clipping here and there but nothing major.Some boss battles are Brilliant!Some redesigns of enemies made them signifcantly cooler without them feeling too different (Centaurs, Pierre, Larson)Replayability through difficulties, timed runs and searching for artifacts and relics.Dangerous areas and climbing puzzles lead to tense jumps a sense of urgency (Saw Blade traps in Egypt)Cons:The Grapple becomes necessary to pass levels and the controls for which can actually be very difficultSome of the later levels don't look or even resemble the original levels in Tomb Raider 1 (1996) (Lost Island Levels)Some of the puzzles were altered and in the case of St. Francis' Folly, a complete different direction has to be taken to get to a certain area, removing the nostalgia of the level.The Boss A.I can be freaking awful (T-Rex and Torso Boss getting stuck on a corner)Some of the redesigns of enemies cause them to look completely different (Mummies, Mutants and Flying Mutants)The Second to last level causing me to have a brain haemorrage because of the jumping platforms and grapple hooks ffs.Bugs regarding ledges and combatI mean the grappling is a serious issue in the game and so can the camera angles. Controls are odd to start with but by the fourth level you will have already pretty much gotten the hang of them. The cheats you unlock later on for completing time trials make the game both easier and a lot more fun. If you're in it for the story or the nostalgia then get it, but don't expect too much from it if you've not played Tomb Raider before, as a matter of fact, if you HAVEN'T played Tomb Raider before, give the first game a go, then you might be able to appreciate the work put into this version of it.From the time racked up on PS2 and on steam, this game is defo worth at least a gander at.

content:
Posted: March 5, 2016
												I actually really like the remake.I'm prepared to conceed there is probably an element of nostalgia here, but I think this is a really fine effort. Graphically with all the options maxed it actually looks pretty good given the era (I think actually it is an excellent example of how solid sound and level design can help a game hold up over time even after the graphics tech has aged - you can still get that 'ah' feeling when you come out of a claustraphobic tunnel into an open and complex area).But the other thing I notice playing this title is what an excellent 3d puzzle platform the old Tomb Raider games were. The control is accurate enough that you can do precision maneouvers cleanly and without glitch frustration, and the puzzles are genuinely enjoyable, pitched at pretty much the right level - not so hard you give up, but difficult enough you can experience a feeling of achievement when you figure something out.Unlike some I quite enjoy the new version of TR also - I enjoy story-heavy gaming and I like bleeding-edge graphics so I'm all there. But the original TR games really were there own thing, something that was clear from sales at the time presumably but is even mroe apparent I feel with the passage of time. I really can't think of many other 'puzzle platformer' titles which worked so successfuly in 3d. (Most 3d puzzle platform games are glitchy horrors.)Atmosphere, puzzles, enough story to keep you engaged, plenty of Raiders of the Lost Ark tropes, really clean control. I'm kind of surprised how much I am enjoying playing Anniversary.Well done those who did the rerelease of this classic title.

Posted: January 5, 2016
												Anniversary is a remake to the original Tomb Raider retooled to be connected with the Legend game. Making this a prequal to that story. The game has the same control scheme as the Legend game along with slightly updated graphics. All of the locations and enemies from the original are all present except with more detail and more cinematic cut scenes. There is more dialoge along with tons of bonus material to unlock such as costumes from the older games for Lara to wear. Not as many outfits as Legend had but the replay value to this game makes it worth while. The added elements to the plot helped made this game not be a carbon copy of the original. The original will forever be a classic, though it is great to see a revised version of the game that started the franchise. With hours of gameplay to endure, any Tomb Raider fan will enjoy this game as much if not more than the original game. Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 29, 2016
												WOW. I am thoroughly blown away by just how amazingly good Tomb Raider: Anniversary is. It is hands down one of the best action-adventure games I have ever played, and I enjoyed myself through the whole game. Having never played a Tomb Raider game before, this was a very pleasant surprise to me.Now I’ll actually tell you about the game. As you probably know, you’ll be playing as Lara Croft, a British archaeologist (and parkour master) who wields two pistols and swings on a grappling hook. The gameplay itself reminds me very heavily of the 3D Legend of Zelda games (Twilight Princess in particular) in that it’s all about solving puzzles, activating switches, fighting enemies, and discovering secret areas to finish levels and move on.Since this game is a remake of the original 1996 Tomb Raider, it shares the same story and environments with that game. However, although locations may look similar, the levels have been completely redesigned and are much different than the original, often involving much more puzzle-solving and combat with enemies than before.Controlling Lara can be a bit cumbersome for you at first as the controls and camera take some time to get used to, but after you play for an hour or so it becomes very simple. The controls are greatly improved from the 1996 original, and it feels much more natural controlling Lara without the tank controls present in the original game. Now WASD actually moves Lara in the direction you press, and the mouse freely controls the camera.The graphics are stunning for a 2007 game – the animated cut-scenes that play at some points during the adventure are very nicely rendered, the environments are extremely detailed, and the in-game models of Lara, enemies, and other characters all look great. There are, however, some minor problems with shadow casting, and Lara can on occasion appear to be floating due to wonky collision boxes on some objects, but these are largely ignorable.All in all, Tomb Raider: Anniversary is a wonderful game, and a great title to start with if you’re looking to get into the Tomb Raider franchise. Anyone who has either played the 1996 original or is brand-new to the series should definitely give it a try.

												I purchased the boxed version back when it was released and decided to give this another belt through upon learning that  Anniversary, Legend and Underworld are all part of its own trilogy that expands and condenses the Tomb raider franchise. So first things first, Graphics, cause I mean c'mon, first thing you notice in a game is looks. Still impresses me, though the textures are looking a bit muddy by todays standards. Sound is great, weapons sound like they feel...if you know what I mean. Gameplay, much more streamlined and easier to control than the original Tomb raider, quicker movements, faster action etc. As a whole, I remember the original TR to be a little longer, maybe it was just me taking my sweet time but I feel that this version is a little more diluted and quicker paced. I've just reached egypt and I'm about 9 hours in through the main game. Anyways, great game if you are new to TR or an old hat to the franchise.

Posted: August 12, 2011
												This is a faithful remake of the original Tomb Raider. The graphics are pretty true to the visual style of the series while also bringing them up to date with the current generation of gaming. Gameplay, however, remains an archaic throwback to a much simpler time. There is very little plot to speak of in this installment (most characters are developed only in the unlockable extras you read after finishing the game) and dialog is few and far between. There are some excellent platforming elements here, but some can be absolutely frustrating due to the uncontrollable camera and loose movement controls. Despite the short length of the game, many platforming sequences and puzzles are repeated with only minor variations. There is very little combat in the game until the final chapter, but that's to be expected. If you've never played a Tomb Raider game before, this isn't a bad place to start. If you're a veteran, the nostalgia along with a few surprises here and there will satisfy.

												Own this on almost every system it's available on, my personal favourite in the series and an absolute blast to play, imho the reboot just doesn't have this atmosphere or as interesting locales as this does, not to mention variety of enemies and complexity of gameplay. In Anniversary you will visit a variety of beautiful locations from Greece to Egypt, fight all manner of beast from lowly rats to a gigantic T-rex and solve slew of deadly and complex puzzles within these trap ridden tombs. This is how tomb raiding should be and is what made the fanchise as popular as it is today!

Posted: August 10, 2014
												Tomb Raider: Anniversary is a classic TR game with a new graphics sheen. In my mind, it's a huge step up from Legend. It's a remake of the first game, but it makes some great changes throughout. Most of the maps are more interesting, the environments are opened up and there's a bit less of the endless stone corridors of the first one.Unfortunately, the combat is not so great. The "power dodge" maneuver adds a bit of interest, but combat mostly feels like a chore. The controls can be a bit clunky, however. The puzzles are great, however, and are the main reason I played the game. Stuff like the Atlas-Poseidon-Damocles-Haphaestus puzzle are really rewarding to work out.All said,  if you enjoy the old-school style of Tomb Raider play, you owe it to yourself to get Anniversary.

content:
Posted: July 17, 2016
												This game is only a slight improvement over legend. It’s still a very average game but unlike legend this game has some aspects to it that I think are intriguing. The fact that it’s a remake to the original makes it interesting in the first place because if you have played the original you are constantly going to be making comparisons between them and seeing what they changed and what they kept the same and there is some fun in doing that. The way the levels are laid out is quite clever but they are not necessarily fun to play through mainly because the visuals are very basic and repetitive. The shooting is the same as legend which I didn’t like, the slow motion dodging head shot mechanic that they added didn’t do anything to improve or add to the shooting in my opinion. The platforming was slightly more fun than legend mainly because of the way the levels are set up, it gave a bit of Prince of Persia feel to it which is always a good thing. Avoiding traps was probably the highlight of the game. Very simplistic story it didn’t really add anything to the experience it’s very minimal and forgettable. I didn’t have much fun playing this game, the moments where I did have fun were too few and far between. There isn’t any good story, good music during gameplay or set pieces to pull you through the game without getting bored. The second half of this game is unbelievably boring, it picks up a bit towards the end but before then, it’s like they threw all their creative ideas in the first half and the second half was an afterthought. A lot of the levels in the second half are very open and empty, feeling lifeless and depressing. The first four chapters are really great I wish the whole game was just as good and judging from a lot of the positive steam reviews of this game, people only played those first 2 great hours of the game and then stopped and decided to review the game before finishing it which is a pet peeve of mine.  It was a choir to play through. 5/10 (Average)

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 25, 2014
												Some remakes feel utterly unnecessary.Then there's Tomb Raider: Anniversary - a perfect example of why remakes should happen.Have you played the original Tomb Raider recently?It doesn't hold up well. It has aged terribly.The graphics are laughably blocky (let's face it, even for its time, Tomb Raider wasn't pretty) and we've got those terrible, muddy, low-res textures... but beyond the superficial cosmetic stuff, there's the unrefined gameplay and ESPECIALLY shoddy controls.If you want the authentic retro experience, you can get the original here on Steam...As a series continues, it is refined. The developers get a handle on what was good; what worked; what didn't... they can learn and grow.Tomb Raider: Anniversary is putting the lessons you've learned over time into practice and fixing your mistakes.Tomb Raider: Anniversary is the original, only better in every way.Visually improved, of course, but VASTLY superior mechanically, and with respect to the controls.What hasn't changed, is Lara's bizarre choice of a tank top and short-shorts for a snowy expedition.I'll accept that she wants to wear that for manoeuvrability, fashion, and/or for hot weather. There's nothing wrong with that. But good gods is it inappropriate for a bloody blizzard!So, poor Lara is sexualised and objectified, but she is still one of gaming's most badass leading ladies; basically "lady Indiana Jones," which is probably one of the most awesome things ever.If you're looking to experience the franchise's story, this is going to be a better entry-point than the PS1-era classic.

content:
Posted: May 19, 2014
												This game is a remake of the original Tomb Raider game from 1996, and it is also the best in the new series of games by Crystal Dynamics. It takes the core ideas from the original and updates them to behave like a modern 3d game should, but without losing the original feel and focus of the original. If you like your TR with giant multi-stage puzzles, a sense of isolation, harsh platforming and animal killing then this is the game you want. Crystal stayed pretty true to the source material while using the newer technology to update it in smart ways, like making areas that should have been big (such as the Colleseum) actually big. Memorable levels like St Francis Folly are back, but now the scale matches how they actually felt to complete the first time. The music is great and it has my favorite Croft Manor level in the series. Overall an amazing remake and one of the textbook examples of how to update a classic while still retaining what made it unique and interesting.For me this is tied with the Resident Evil remake for the Gamecube as best remake.

number of helpful: 4 of 7 people (57%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 3, 2014
												If you can get over the game-breaking bugs, the terrible and incredibly touchy controls (the HORRIBLE ROPE SWINGING sections), and the outdated graphics and animation, the gameplay loop is actually pretty fun. The puzzles are all decent, but traversing (when the controls aren't working against you) is the real star here. When you nail a segment of really quickly timed jumps, the feeling is awesome. The story is throwaway and mostly uninteresting, but I still found enough fun in this game to mostly recommend it. There were still huge sections of the game where I thought I might have an emotional breakdown with how bad the controls are and what the game is demanding of you. If you go into the game expecting the worst and are okay with that, give this a go and you'll probably enjoy it.

												pros: runs stable on win7, graphically updated to a higher standard than the original, varied environments, soundtrack fits the theme, some puzzles are very well designed, exponentially better boobs on Lara compared to the originalcons: clunky movement and controls, derpy camera angles, combat is basic and repetative, unable to scroll multiple targets when aiming, quick-time-events during cut scenes, bosses are tedious to fight (they always require bullet time), I found the fog/dust and blur effects disruptive, storyline and ending is dullOverall, this is an updated game to the first and classic Tomb Raider 1 (not to be confused with the lame 2013 title), and does deserve some attention from where the genre had its beginings. content:
Posted: March 24, 2015
												Short review, based on approx. 36h playing TR:Anniversary (100% mastered)[Personal setup: never played TR:1 (on wich TR:Anniversary is based on) or another TR-release before, except for the latest release "Tomb Raider". Got lots of pleasant anticipation. Don't do Jump'n'Run games generally. I like trying to "master" games if they're fun, regarding the game-content as well as skill]- Nice graphics (as for the releasedate of the game) and superb leveldesign- Nice soundtrack- Smooth animation of the acrobatics and great variety of possible movements- Laras facial expressions and body language are decent- Very smooth gameplay; exceptions:-- The annoying moment when Lara got hit by enemies-- The autoaim when confronted by multiple enemies- Wide range of challenges and difficulties- Up to 30-40h fun (or temporary rage) with the game, depending on how much time you spend with collecting artifacts/relics or solving puzzles, or wether you do the time trials- Ridiculous story and characters. The storyline is utterly nonsense, but does not impact the gameplay. The cut scenes therefore are structuring the chapters and procure orientation- Quick time events are one nice feature- Lots of (more or less interesting) bonus content (such as drafts, soundtracks, char-bios, outfits)Conclusion: HIGHLY recommended for ambitious players.

content:
Posted: March 6, 2012
												Best "Tomb Raider" of the new generation.If I was to decsribe this game then the first sentence would be it. It's true to the original format and idea of the game, has some very well made graphics and design that will not kill your computer, has puzzles that are in fact challenging and has nice hard to find secrets for the completionists. The story and cutscenes are made fun to watch and the game provides extra details like developer commentary and a little note to the fans. If your a fan from the first Tomb Raider then you will love this game and will enjoy some nostalgia. Likewise, if your new to the series this is the game I would recommend you start off with. The game will allow you to see the original idea and design in all its glory so if you enjoy it you can decided if this is a series you would like to play more.Keep in mind for new players, this is a puzzle game first and foremost, the combat and bosses can be enjoyable but this is not the main attraction of the game.

content:
Posted: February 29, 2016
												This game is next in the series after Tomb Raider Legend. As such, I played Legend first and it was a good game. This game, however, has many more problems, some of which are literally game-breaking.For starters, the story is not made as clear as in Legend. I knew why Lara was doing things and there were enough cutscenes to keep me filled in. In Anniversary though, the cutscenes are few, and they are far-between. The main reason you should not get this game is the following: while the puzzles and parkour are much more difficult and challenging (not a bad thing), the game is WAY more picky about exactly when you hit the button, exactly where you are standing, small things like that that seem like not a big deal until you are browsing youtube for tutorials because you think you're just doing it wrong and find out you've been doing it right the whole time, its the game not letting you drag the block, or grab with your grappeling hook, or just simple things like that that wreck the game when they don't work, even after restarting the game, reloading the level, restarting the computer. Its like they released it without making sure small things like that still worked and when they don't, the game is literally broken and you can't continue even though you're doing what you are supposed to be doing. Ugh!

content:
Posted: October 3, 2015
												In some ways it is a decent game, but as I progressed, it became unplayable for me.It started off ok, but as the puzzles and boss fights got harder, they got more tedious, and the controls got more frustrating. After a while the puzzles feel repetitive (but this is largely a question of personal taste). 95% of the game is pure puzzle platforming (so you should only play this if you really like that sort of gameplay). My playthrough broke down to frustrating trial and error at times. I found the keyboard/mouse controls difficult and at times inconsistent and unresponsive - Maybe it plays better on a console. I got stuck on some of the platforming and boss fights, so I had to look up the solutions online. I'm not a noob, but better hints and tutorials would have been helpful for me. It is also a pity there is no manual save system, and that the save checkpoints are not very forgiving - they were often far away from the part I struggled with, meaning I had to redo a lot after failing a sequence. Also, you have to manually “save” the checkpoint, otherwise, if you quit/reload, you lose all progress since the beginning of the game. Dare I say it, but this game may be too “hardcore” for me (even though I usually don't like it when games are dumbed down). While the experience was too frustrating for me, this is quite a good game within its specific genre.If you like difficult platforming and old-school boss fights, you may like this game. Otherwise, there are simply too many flaws, so I sadly cannot recommend it.

number of helpful: 7 of 14 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
												Don't buy this game. It is a huge upgrade from the original Tomb Raider, but it still suffers significant camera issues.  Often you will find yourself unable to figure out where to go without dying a few times just to find a platform to jump to which isn't right if the game doesn't have a quick save function.  The game suffers from clipping issues where you will find yourself jumping onto a ledge but you failed the jump and the character is stuck in a few pixels and she is in a state of constant falling but you can't jump or move because she is stuck and you have to wait for her to fall and die.  On top of that, the game suffers from terrible mechanics (or unresponsiveness to commands) where you are hanging off a cliff or ledge and there is only 1 direction to jump to and the character chooses to jump to another direction and ultimately failing the jump.  It is such a pet peeve for me that a game with such terrible mechanics dares to have time trials to make this game a challenge when the mechanics itself are the challenge.  A lot of the times the jumps are basically how lucky you are as a few pixels off and you're falling off a ledge.  The grapple-wall-running jump is the worst thing ever in this game.  The camera angle is constantly changing while you run along the wall and instead of a left right motion, you have to go from left to up and then down to right to gain maximum swing momemtum but when you jump at the end the direction you are pressing can impact the jump to forward or outwards, even though you have one direction you want the jump to (other direction will result death).  However, at the same time, these directions are inconsistent where sometimes you will jump outwards or forward with the same direction pressed.  This game needs a 3rd remake.  Honestly, people who rated this game positively has likely never finished the game (low game play time) or had tremendous luck getting those jumps.  This game has nice graphics and an interesting story for it's age but it did not age well with mechanics.  It is like old school 3d final fantasy games with broken camera angles.

content:
Posted: September 22, 2015
  TL;DR  : A good Tomb Raider game overall (from what I've played, knowing 2 chapters), but this game is way too buggy to be played on PC. I don't know if it's better on console but I really don't recommand buying it on steam.   Story / SettingTomb Raider: Anniversary is a remake of the first Tomb Raider game, the story is absolutely the same, but they did a good job at creating a game that is very influenced by the first one but not exactly the same with better graphics. I didn't finish the game but the story is really typical for a Tomb Raider game.GameplayFirst of all: the reason I don't recommand it. The ennemies and certain parts of levels are simply not playable, its just too buggy. Most ennemies get stuck and there's not any challenge, I got to a point at a boss fight were all I had to do was shoot at it and wait for it to die. Some of the game mechanics are also very buggy, I often see through the textures and I couldn't access some areas. There's also this: http://i.imgur.com/Zg331C4.jpg . Which is pretty funny but became a bit annoying :p Except that, it's overall a good Tomb Raider game, pretty classic. It's really something between the very first Tomb Raiders and Tomb Raider Legend. As far as I played, the puzzles and secrets were too easy, especially compared to early Tomb Raider games and TR Legend, but hopefully they become more difficult later. PerformanceRunned at very high fps on max settings (i5 4690 / R9 390) Style / Graphics It really looks like TR Legend, with obviously a TR1 inspiration for Lara and the levels. A good looking game.

content:
Posted: March 3, 2016
												My experience has been that the real challenge of the game is the bugs. I think it'd been a lovely game, if it wasn't so buggy in every aspect, which is surprising considering just how few mechanics there are to use in the game.AI bugs involve just shooting at the first boss for 20 minutes, because he's just stuck doing his walking animation in the same spot unable to attack or move. The same goes for some of the 8-10 total different kinds of enemy creatures(this is not an exaggeration) in the game.There's also annoying glitches, where trying to run over the edge of a ledge to hang from it ends with Lara just spassing out as she slowly falls further and further until she suddenly drops to her death.The checkpoint system is also pretty poorly implemented in my opinion. A lot of the puzzles are so millimeter precise, for example in terms of jumping, that you often have to redo them all the way through, because you end up falling to your death. Once you respawn, you have to watch every single cinematic again that might be involved in the puzzles, which gets really tiresome. Besides of how strict the puzzles are, you sometimes end up doubting, if you're doing the right thing, until you finally get it right.I've also encountered bugs, where I had no choice but to reload an earlier save. For example at the beginning of the Egypt chapter, where no matter where and how I grappled the rocks you're supposed to pull down, they just wouldn't fall down.As I said, if it wasn't for the incredibly, incredibly buggy, frustrating gameplay, I think it would've been an okay game. The story is extremely sparse. Considering there are only 4(?) chapters in the game, and you just skip straight from chapter 2 to 3 with no storytelling in between, it seems like the story didn't take the highest priority.The best thing I can say about the game is that it has some beautifully looking levels, but that's about the only good thing I can say. I've never written a review for a game before, but this feels like a product that should still be thoroughly tested. There are such few mechanics and types of enemies in the game, and considering this is an anniversary edition, I'm really, really surprised that two of the biggest aspects in the game are so buggy that I encounter these abovementioned things at what I'd guesstimate to be half the puzzles, and a fifth of the enemies.

content:
Posted: December 17, 2015
												Nice platformer with weak fighting parts, that has aged very well in the last 8 Years, but has frustrating problems by design or glitches.Sometimes I gave up only to find out from some LP videos, that I already tried the correct solution (many times).I remember one simple 90 degree jump from a ledge to a platform that never worked because a small nose left and right of the platform (where it was attached to the wall) prevented Lara from reaching the platform ( worked for me when jumping while also pressing the right camera stick to look at the platform). There is one ring on the top of a wooden ramp (that looks like a door while closed) that cannot be targeted with the hook unless you switch to manual targeting ("R3" on Gamepad). There are two rooms where you have to lift four columns - I think one of the rooms cannot be finished when you go down too early without lifting the first column on your way down.I had general problems jumping backwards from a swinging rope or Lara missing the tip of columns as targets.Near the end there are some jump combos for which you have to know how to do fast combos while a countdown is running and you have to be ready to try it dozens of times even knowing the correct solution.When I wanted to continue after the "Lost Valley" my savegame started in "Lost Valley" again and I hadn't collected any of the three cogs. Luckily I had a manual save.To survive later boss fights you need to know how to perform the "Adrenaline Dodge" action and it requires some timing skills. The last boss teases you that you will run out of ammo eventually. As you have unlimited ammo that isn't true, but you might run out of med-packs if you try to win by "adrenaline dodging" left or right.The game is okay for the low price and if you are happy only looking into it for a few hours.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2015
												I just finished this game and it is probably the most frustrating game I have ever played. Controls and especially camera control is very unpredictable so in many jumps Lara just jumps in WTF directions you would never expect. That with combination with the possibility to save the game only at predefined checkpoints, which are quite poorly chosen lots of times, makes a receipt for many repetitive tries where you have to go trough a long pasage of jumps just to try your luck at a difficult one. And when I write luck, I mean it, the game is full of bugs, where sometimes under some circumstances (such as particular resolution settings) you just can't make it. Some situations are also very unpredictable, because the length of the jumps varies at different places, so you can't be sure, if Lara will make it. On the other hand sometimes you ignore a place because you are "sure" that she can't make it that far, but if you watch a walktrough - yay, that was the solution!All of the above could be forgiven if the plot and the puzzles were really good, but neither is IMO. The puzzles are really repetitive and because of the mechanics, controls and bugs really annoying. There are only two or three really original puzzles which I ejoyed. Boss fights are really boring as well, once you figure out, how to defeat someone, there is always a phase, where you have to repeat the moves dozen of times, before it is finished.In conlusion as I wrote In the first sentence, this is a really frustrating game with almost no fun aspects. The only possitive thing I can say about this is that some of the locations are really pretty.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 9, 2016
												Pros: - Great looking game. Laura character model is fantastic looking and the scenery is good as well.- Sounds are also quite good. - Puzzles are challenging but (mostly) possible (except one).- Runs decently. A huge improvement from Legends.Cons:- Can't alt-tab. Isn't a big issue for most but since I streamed the game, it's a huge concern. Alt-tabbing will cause the game to black out and not reload.- Camera angles. Camera can sometimes zoom in too close to Laura basically obscuring the scenary around Laura. The camera can also be quite restrictive while doing jumping puzzles, basically meaning you can't see the ledge that you need to jump to. The movement can also fail to coordinate with the camera, causing you to move in an unintended direction. While this is largely limited to wall puzzles again, this game also has a lot of timed puzzles, so wasting time trying to re-coordinate your orientation generally ends with dissappointing results.- Fixed animations. A lot of actions result in going through a short animation of a couple of seconds. Some of these a useful as they are a visual cue for things; the turning animation for wall running is the point where you are supposed to reverse jump for example. However, most tend to cause unintended consequences with interactions with other elements of the game. Getting knocked down is an understandable consequence for some attacks, but enemies' attacks are not timed according to those animations, meaning you can get hit multiple times while trying to recover, or worst, get knocked back again and wait another cycle to recover. Another annoying animation is the animation of holstering weapons after activating buttons with countdowns which can cost 2 seconds of your time before you regain control of the camera and proper movement. At the later levels, uneven textures, like walls in the cave, completely mess up the turning animation.- Jumping movement is inconsistent and glitchy. Doing the same jumps at the same spot can yield inconsistent results. At times, if you just happen to be at the wrong spot, your jump can go off in a random direction, except the direction that you intended of course. Because a lot of paths are scripted, a lot of jumps can also fail simply because you are not in the right spot to trigger Laura to catch the ledge/object. On occasion, she may decided not to jump at all despite you pressing and holding the jump key.The sliding slopes can also glitch out on you, starting the jump animation to make you think to jump only for Laura to stagger and just slide straight off. - Combat. Combat is like Legends (iirc), mainly lock-on but with manual aim for some instances. Now while the combat in Legends had issues, with basic enemies, it sufficed. Anniversary has a) significantly more flying enemies b) mainly melee enemies. The combat system in this game does not allow for much manual control on the move meaning you're completely at the mercy of the auto-targeting. The camera can't be moved manually as well and also has a very low ceiling. So basically the only way to properly switch targets is to untarget, wait for the holster animation to finish and hope to isolate the intended enemy in your view as you retarget. Also, it can auto-retarget at random.Another part of the combat is the slow-motion sequences where you need to initiate a dodge to get a targeting sequence. At times, the dodge won't work and or the aiming sequence won't trigger. There are also times, the camera angle can also deface causing you to be unable to see the aiming sequence occuring. You can also get attacked by other enemies in this sequence, which can cancel the sequence or make it impossible to react to an attack.For a game that requires precise timings in a lot of actions, it is both clunky as well as forces control away from the player in a lot of circumstances, this results in a poor gameplay experience overall. For a game where I enjoyed for about 60% of time, this quickly dissipated once more and more precision and reaction was expected of me, except that most of it was out of my control because of things like the camera not allowing me to see what I need to jump to or simply because I can't aim at what I need to shoot above my head. For all that I enjoyed in this game, it's basically meaningless when it comes to me actually needing to judge it on its gameplay quality, because a) this is a game, and b) the core mechanics that define this franchise and genre don't work properly.There are also other issues like the 1st boss getting stuck in a corner and me spending a good 15 mins shooting at it while it remains there, and one particular segment where the only way to backtrack on a error in the puzzle is to maually reload to the last checkpoint (btw, this game doesn't have a return to last checkpoint feature, it's completely up to you saving the last checkpoint if you want to return to them. Otherwise, the only option is to die, which will automatically send you to it.) Bosses are quite grindy as well. I honestly felt that there was more technique required in Legends. One of the puzzles, near the end, is also nonsensically difficult, mainly because of a combinations of the issues mentioned above coupled with a very tight countdown timer. It took me about 4hrs to complete that part and was almost the breaking point as there was no other was to progress. Otherwise, as I stated at the start, they are quite fun to do.In the end, I would only recommend this game to hard core fans of the genre and/or Tomb Raider and if you are willing to tolerate inconsistant movement and a lot of trial and error type puzzles. Otherwise, it can be a fustrating experience at core points that are needed to progress through the game.

content:
Posted: October 13, 2012
												Believe it or not i have never played through a Tomb Raider game.  Since the soon to be released reboot of the series is almost certainly going to wreck the franchise, I figured now was a good time to play through one of the seminal franchises of the Golden Age of Video Games.At its core, Tomb Raider is a puzzle game.  The gameplay was a well thought out blend of old school and new school, making it feel nostalgic yet playable here in 2012.  It was really fun to enter into a room, navigate the environment and piece together the puzzle to advance the game.  It was classic Tomb Raider to be sure.Visually TRA was an unexpected surprise, taking the 2007 era game engine and adding in an advanced set of PC options.  Being able to take nintendo's original sex symbol and max out the graphics settings certainly makes playing through this title easy on the eyes.The only complaint is the needlessly contrived boss battles.  Total immersion breakers for me.But all in all, TRA is a winner.

content:
Posted: December 12, 2015
												Oh boy, this game... I want so badly to like it, but there are things that just make this so difficult to enjoy. The controls are atrocious. For one thing, that wall-run mechanic makes so little sense. If you're used to modern Lara Croft or even just Mirror's Edge, be warned, the mechanics here are nothing like that. Combat mechanics are another reason why I so dislike this game. When I punch right, Lara goes left, right over a ledge and into a pit of fiery death. Then there's the awful adrenaline dodge mechanic, which is alright for users with controllers, but horrible for PC users. You have to be moving for that mechanic to work, and oh, don't shoot at the enemy until the targets line up! This mechanic works okay if you're in single-boss fights, but with multiple enemies, this is impossible. You have an array of unlockables available, but this game really borders on the frustrating rather than challenging side of gaming. You may lose your mind. I certainly did at least a dozen times. My advice to you: play the originals if you can, otherwise, pick this up on console. I got it for like $2 on sale, so if you really want it, wait for that. Don't burn your cash on this. PC controls are awful. The game was enjoyable up until the final couple of levels, where I am now stuck and deliberating whether or not to continue. Get the newer ones and skip this one, please, for your sanity, my fellow PC users!

content:
Posted: January 16
This is review 2 of 3 in my Tomb Raider Legends timline review series.Tomb Raider: Anniversary is a wonderful update of the original Tomb Raider (the very first one!). I'm not even going into the graphical differences (which seems too obvious and too easy to target; suffice to say that the Legends engine is a good upgrade), but instead talk about the level design. Platforming is more intense, since they can afford the bigger spaces. The puzzles are still based on the original puzzles in the first Tomb Raider game, but they definitely were amped up in the difficulty department. With better graphics comes more defined details, and so you get puzzles where you have to look closely at your surroundings to see where you have to go next. Similar to Legends, the next place you're supposed to parkour your way to is easily defined by the lighter color of the ledge, but this time, better accented by the dark niches they create in the rock. The worst part of platforming here was the rope swinging bits. The controls weren't very forgiving, and the timing of some of the jumps felt awkward. I spent the most time on this game than on the other two.The plot also followed that of the original game, so I was surprised to see this as part of the Legends timeline. Its impact to the overall story won't be seen until Underworld though, so the game is almost better appreciated on its own.Out of all 3 games, this one had the best combat system for me. Which is a total shame considering how underwhelming the final boss battle was for me. All the bosses in each level so far was interesting, and revolved around a neat mechanic that needed some skill to adapt to. However, in the final battle with Natla, once you figured out what you needed to do, and pretty much mastered the Adrenaline Dodge (which you will likely have by the time you reach this part), then the battle is pretty much in the bag.All in all, the new engine allowed for larger puzzles and larger areas creating new and interesting changes to the original puzzles, all of which, of course, were very much welcome. An awesome update to a classic, and definitely a must-play for any casual or hardcore fan of Lara Croft.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2015
												Recommended... IF you have a controller.I'm trying to play through this game with the keyboard controls, but it's so frustrating. One jump expects me to jump left, then activate the grappling hook. You need to hit the grappling hook immediately after jumping; there's just one problem. The default control setup requires you to use your ring finger (the weakest finger) for both left AND the grappling hook. Minor issues like these, coupled with the fact that combat is a complete mess (you use one hand on the mouse to shoot & move the camera, while your other hand has to handle moving Lara, jumping, AND rolling) makes using a controller necessary to enjoy this game to the fullest. I have this game on PS2 as well, and it controls like a dream with a dual analog controller. I personally don't have an Xbox 360 controller for my PC yet, so I have to make do with the keyboard for now. Blegh.Other than the awful controls, the game is great. The graphics and framerate are a big step up from the Wii and PS2 versions, although I personally would've liked to see the flashlight and the extra puzzles from the Wii version make an appearance. Got this game for like a dollar when the TR Collection was on sale, so it was well worth the money. If you like Tomb Raider, you'll love this carefully crafted remake of the original. Here's hoping for a Tomb Raider Anniversary 2!

												Probably the best Tomb Raider made (aside from Tomb Raider II). Controls are spot on, (mostly; sometimes glitchy in certain circumstances)  one of the main things I was looking forward to in the reboot, which failed miserably. Simple things, such as tapping the button repeatedly to move faster while climbing. The puzzles are genius. Gameplay stays interesting throughout the whole game up until the final boss- which was the only part I didn't like. I've played this game on every platform it's come out for and I have to say, despite the console, it really retains the quality one each console. The graphics are great and the PC version runs perfectly on even some of the most ancient computers. It really is a shame Square took over the series and seem to only focus on the graphics & "action" rather than the aerobics of which Tomb Raider was born in to. I wish they'd have remade Tomb Raider II before this series went downhill.

content:
Posted: September 26, 2015
												Overall an OK game.It starts as a good game but declines towards the end. There are times where everythings works fluently and then all of a sudden you have some parts where one easy misjudged jump makes you repeat a section over and over. At a couple of spots it is hard to tell if you have the right idea or not. And when you do the move and fail you might have to redo lots of previous moves to get to the same point, because there are no real saves, only checkpoints. These are mostly well placed, but sometimes I'd wish I could save anywhere. This way trial and error would be for fun and less aggravating.The camera ranges from good to bad. Sometimes jumping is more like taking a leap of faith than proper planning. It's really bad when the camera decides where you should look.Movement is generally ok, but there are some very difficult to pull off moves like the one jumping off a wall after swinging on a rope. It only worked by pure chance for me. This is also why the games becomes tedious at the end. More and more puzzles demand advanced moves and then it's less fun if they constantly fail.Moves were also sometimes buggy. So it happens that Lara moves hanging on a pole towards the wall even though I'm pressing and looking in the direction she should swing. Or... sometimes she simply doesn't hold onto a ledge after jumping down. It's not overall bad, but feels unpolished sometimes.I didn't like the gun play at all. Sure, it is easy enough with lock-on and unlimited ammo, but often you get in close combat with an enemy and then it's just frantic shooting until he dies, because it's impossible to follow the enemy with that camera.What's missing is a good journal that tells you at least a little bit what to do at the moment. The included journal is a joke and gives either no hints or cryptic ones that didn't help at all.But overall it's still worth playing if you are a fan of Tomb Raider. I did play the original an honestly, didn't notice any huge resemblences. Mabe I played the original too long ago :D

Posted: December 21, 2015
												In short : 10 / 10 !This is serious stuff ! I have played the original back then on Playstation 1, the second one as well. Those were the games the whole legacy was built on ! This is THE Tomb Raider WITH modern looks: an Excellent HD-Remake! I just reinstalled the Tomb Raider Reboot, which i love really much, but this game man! The first 2 levels provide actually more challenge than the whole Reboot! That's a shooter with minor original Tomb Raider elements, while being also a really great game. If you want to know why Tomb Raider became legendary, this is the game to play! Excellent platformer which WILL bring you challenge even on medium ! Opening ancient gates have never brought so much satisfaction due to the amount of logic and effort required.Recommended!

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												Boring because of the constant repetition when you are trying to find you way through many of the rooms and the correct jump sequences; which results in a lot of misses even when you know what to do; and there are far too few checkpoints for restarts.  The save system is largely useless.  Saves only artifacts found, which are useless in game and only unlock useless info later, but saves none of the useful stuff you need.  Game simply restarts at specific checkpoints after deaths, often erasing much work to be repeated over and over.  Soon you could care less about what should be the most interesting challenges: finding all of the artifacts and relics.  You just play to get what you have to.  Looking at walkthroughs destroys the fun, but is necessary to avoid much boredom.  You continue playing only if a friend is also playing and you encourage each other.

content:
Posted: April 20
												So where do I start? A game that does not recognize my dedicated video card could probably be it, but what annoys me most is this: wonky physics, deceptive hitboxes, unintuitive controls, lousy mechanics, no manual reload and HAVING TO ♥♥♥♥ING MANUALLY SAVE IN 2017!? It's like the developers went back to the 90s in the absolute WORST possible way, bringing back exactly what we dread of the era. This game feels old and outdated, the puzzles make no sense and are not intuitive whatsoever, and what's more, you can't experiment because literally everything hurts Lara! You fall from 3 feet? Damage. You missjudge a jump? Damage. You encounter a poorly placed enemy that makes no sense? Damage. You don't avoid a trap because the camera keeps giving you the worst possible angles? Damage.When I saw my Sherpa coated with a thick fur coat and snow hat, while Lara was wearing her tank top and short shorts atop a friggin mountain, under snow I said "ok video game logic, let's ignore that". But having wolves and bears in a friggin cave that has been locked for god knows how long, without sunlight or any discernible source of food? So much for my suspension of disbelief. If you want to go back to the 90s gaming era, remember what you hated about those games, and appreciate XXI century gaming, get this, no questions asked. If you want a game with good mechanics, decent physics and immersive, steer right away from this, this is all the issues of last century gaming rolled into one.

content:
Posted: January 12, 2015
												I do not recommend this game for the fans of the classic Tomb Raider series.Though, newcomers to the series might see this in a total different perspective then I do.Growing up and seeing my dad play Tomb Raider 1 on the PC and getting a PSX with Tomb Raider 2 as my 1st game around x-mas back when I was 8 years old made Tomb Raider an unforgetable experience and became one of my favorite game franchises to date.The original TR1 was way more open and not as linear as Tomb Raider: Anniversary. Yes, the graphical improvement is amazing (even now it still looks stunning at times - game dates from 2007) but the game is very linear and makes it so you can only follow one straight path towards the end, which is sad knowing that the original game you really had to spend time searching how to solve puzzles and not to get lost in the maze.Still, some places really brought Tomb Raider 1 back amazingly well. St. Francis Folly is one of the examples that made me happy to see it in a different way then what they were capable of back in 1996.In the end, it depends what you are looking for in this game.Diverse gameplay, searching around, solving puzzles? You'd better check out the original.Fast-paced gameplay with ofcourse a big boost graphic wise? Then TR:A is your thing.

												EARLY ACCESS REVIEWIf your looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if your looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.Ingredients:1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter2. 1/2 cup white sugar3. 1/2 cup brown sugar4. 1/4 cup water5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon6. 1 pinch salt7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie Directions:1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

content:
Posted: October 26, 2014
												This game is faithful to the original: exotic destinations, beautiful sceneries, ominous creatures... The graphics are outdated but still manage to convey the atmosphere; the game design stays in the slow paced puzzle spirit. So it's a welcomed opportunity to rediscover a classic of video games.Unfortunately the developers did a terrible job at implementing the controls and the camera, resulting in extremely inaccurrate moves. In a gameplay consisting in half puzzle, half platformer, where mistakes are immediately punished, it makes the experience painfully frustrating.All in all, the only thing this remake brings, is 2000's graphics. Other than that, the level design is mostly the same (which is good though), the controls are bad, the menus are rushed, and there are bugs that can block the progression altogether. Not much for Crystal Dynamics to be proud of really.

number of helpful: 10 of 25 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 2, 2016
												This game is yet another reason why I wish I didn't have to recommend or not recommend a game.  It's right on the border and should probably receive a push.The positive aspects of this game is it's an amazingly updated version of the original Tomb Raider, to the point where there's no reason to go back and play the original, unless you want to have a bad experience. The game is updated enough to use gamepads, better graphics, and better game play. But there's a major issue.  This game was released in 2007, the previous year Crystal Dynamics offered Tomb Raider Legend and honestly I think Tomb Raider Legends is a far superior game. The two games are night and day and I prefer Tomb Raider Legends, the previous year's game by a significant amount.  To me that makes it near impossible to recommend this.  The biggest difference in-between the game is Tomb Raider Legends is the game flow in Tomb Raider legend is more solid.  The game moves between puzzles and combat with ease, and while the combat in Tomb Raider Legend is harder (due to soldiers).  The player constantly feels like they are making progress.  Where as in Tomb Raider Anniversary, the small combat in the game is more an annoyance (or a total slog as in the T-rex Boss fight).  And the puzzles take the center stage, while they are bigger or more expansive, the player often doesn't know what he's doing, or what he's doing wrong.  This just gets frustrating.  The trick in Tomb Raider legend is Lara constantly talks with her friends, which while it can be annoying, it gives the player something to do, and a clue to know when they did something right.  Instead in Tomb Raider Anniversary, the first half of the game is almost dead silent.   The player feels alone, and not in a positive way. The biggest problem is Tomb Raider legends is just a more interesting game.  There's a story, and interesting and diverse levels, and something going on, where Anniversary is Lara raiding tombs but not even talking to herself about it, and after a long enough time, it's dull and tiresome.  This is a remake with upgraded everything, I really wish they made the story and game a little better, and didn't feel like they just changed the engine and called it a day. Is Tomb Raider Anniversary a bad game?  No.  It's not, it's extremely playable, and actually quite nice compared to the original game.  However it does very little better than Tomb Raider Legend, lacks a story and while it's graphics work with a 2007 sensibility, the game which might have worked in 2007 is no longer good enough in 2016I know this game is a fan favorite, or a nostalgic classic, and it's more difficult than Legend's puzzles but the difficulty comes from lack of guidance, and weak controls, rather than gameplay elements.  Good puzzle games can let the player know where they should go or what they're missing with out solving the puzzle.  Anniversary doesn't even attempt that.  It tosses the player in the deep end and lets them drown with out a word.

												This game is faithful to the original: exotic destinations, beautiful sceneries, ominous creatures... The graphics are outdated but still manage to convey the atmosphere; the game design stays in the slow paced puzzle spirit. So it's a welcomed opportunity to rediscover a classic of video games.Unfortunately the developers did a terrible job at implementing the controls and the camera, resulting in extremely inaccurrate moves. In a gameplay consisting in half puzzle, half platformer, where mistakes are immediately punished, it makes the experience painfully frustrating.All in all, the only thing this remake brings, is 2000's graphics. Other than that, the level design is mostly the same (which is good though), the controls are bad, the menus are rushed, and there are bugs that can block the progression altogether. Not much for Crystal Dynamics to be proud of really.

content:
Posted: March 7
 WHEN A GOOD GAME SCREWS YOU OVER  A Fix included if you experience this issue I played this game a long time ago back on PS3 or Xbox 360... i cant remember which as i had both.Anyway, The game itself plays fine (at least as far as i got) however i got screwed over by some stupid save profile glitch. I must have played an hour or so (not far past the T-Rex) went and saved and then closed the game. (as any other working game) I come back later and the "profile" doesn't recognise my save and makes me start the game over, of course after some research the solution i found was ... make 2 profiles and for some reason that did allow you to return to a save but i lost my progress in the research and testing and have to start from the beginning. Now while 1 hour is not to bad to have to recover, but i was only interested in playing this game once then uninstalling it. Now i just don't care, the game gave me a crummy glitch and im not bothering to start over again. You might think this is a dumb review but i'm just being honest. So...  Conclusion The 1 Hour i got to play and from what i remember of it was a good game. Don't get me wrong, the game is good and i don't like giving it a negative review, If i didnt have this bug and or maybe was more keen to play this enough to start again, i would give it a positive.Again i'm just being honest, it P!ssed me off that i lost all that progress and found a fix too late. Maybe i'm in the unlucky group of people who had this happen to them... but it happened. So if you purchase this game and are reading this review for some insight or a heads up. (Fix found on the steam forums)1. Create a new profile and exit the game2. Go to C:\Users\USERNAME\Documents\Eidos\Tomb Raider - Anniversary3. Copy the content from the old profile to the new profile4. Start a new game with your new profile5. Once in-game, open up the options menu and you should see your savegames.6. Load your latest savegame and - just in case - save again, using a new savegame.

number of helpful: 1 of 7 people (14%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 16, 2014
												Nice game.My playthrough info: I played on Easy, as always. Used an XBox-360 gamepad, and generally did not consult walkthroughs. I made the review after completing the game itself -- I haven't completed Croft Manor yet, and I'm still missing two secrets in the main game. I'm not a fast player, so it took me about 45 hours to get to that stage.I've started some old Tomb Raider games over the years, but never played them for long. This one... I finished it. And I'm planning to play the next one too. I didn't play the previous one due to Anniversary being advertised as a remake of the first Tomb Raider, but I might go back to that eventually too.One might have to take a break every once in a while. You get to explore caves and ruins of ancient civilizations, filled with magic devices and traps and the occasional monster thingy to shoot. When you've finished that you get to the next area, where you get to explore caves and ruins of ancient civilizations, filled with magic devices and traps and the occasional monster thingy to shoot. After completing that... well, you get the idea, I hope :-)So for me it did help to a take the occasional break. It didn't get "boring", though. Ok, maybe towards the end when almost every switch you flipped didn't just do the usual thing but also freed another monster thingy to shoot.Being a puzzle-platformer with secrets and stuff, don't expect to just rush through the areas. It may appear impossible at times, but after a few retries you get an idea how things might work. Lara has the uncanny ability to just come back from the dead at a convenient location when she dies, so experimentation is key: can I jump there, or can I not? Well, lets try it...Even finding the secrets works out ok: everything in a level is there to be used in some way. So if you've reached the exit, and there's a ledge or pole or box or something else somewhere that you haven't even touched, chances are that there's another way leading somewhere you haven't been yet.The game has plenty of checkpoints. In fact, on at least one occasion when I had to do a timed run to reach a secret (flip the switch to open the door, then reach it before it closes again) I had to make sure to avoid the checkpoint on the way, so I could just die and respawn at the checkpoint before the switch instead of having to reload that manual save or having to get to the switch again.In most cases, though, hitting a checkpoint is more of a reward than a curse: you've completed a section of the area, and it's now safely behind you.Just know this: search the area for switches and stuff. Take your time looking at the rooms. Swim through every pool looking for stuff underwater. Jump on every rock that you can jump on. If that's not something you want to do throughout the entire game, don't play this. In most areas there's hardly any enemies to kill -- this isn't Borderlands. The game is about reaching the exit, and there's never a straight and easy path with signs.For the bossfights, I did look up the dino since at the time I hadn't figured out the whole andrenaline dodge thing. Never used it on normal enemies anyway. I also looked up the centaurs since nothing I did seemed to work. For the other bosses, the game did a better job of "guiding" my actions, so all in all even the bosses worked out nicely. Even the final boss felt like it was supposed to be killed -- some games focus their bosses on merely frustrating the player.I did have the occasional problem with the gamepad controls, but that's probably just my skills. At one point I even checked a walkthrough to see whether I really have to take the route that I thought I have to take, and after confirming that I used a Flytool to get past that to the next checkpoint. But that only happened once towards the end. I'm still missing two artifacts, one of which I think I know, but having control issues again -- but these aren't essential, so I can just try it every once in a while.PS: since the shop page provides no trailers, here's two of them.

												Don't EVER buy this. Don't even play it if it's free. All the things that make Tomb Raider what it is; the movement, the navigation, the environments, the enemies...they are all glitched to hell. And I don't mean 'a bit glitchy', I mean completely ruined. Sometimes game-stoppingly so. This has been released on several platforms, but I would bet money that this has had zero testing on this version.There was one glitch where she wouldn't grab on to a ledge because she kept hitting something sticking out in the wall, and there was no other way round it. After some researching, I found out that lots of people have been having the same problem, and the only way for her to grab the ledge is to turn the aspect ratio down and full screen effects off. I'm not even ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ you, then and only then did she clip through the rock on the wall and grab the ledge.Plus, it saves checkpoints as you progress through milestones in a level. Sometimes you fall down or something and may wish to start at the checkpoint instead of making your way all the way to it again. The only way to do this is to kill Lara somehow. If there isn't any water around, you have to dive onto the floor from high up. If she survives this, whatever you do, DO NOT LOAD SAVED GAME! It puts you right back at the ♥♥♥♥ing start of the level. There is no 'Load Checkpoint' option. You either kill her or you make your way back to the checkpoint. I've lost about 2 hours of gameplay and counting so far because of this. I've learned my lesson the 2nd time now.BLAAAAAAAAM THIS PIECE OF CRAP~Solar out

content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												I'd never played a Tomb Raider before the reboot and now I'm grateful I hadn't. There are plenty of huge issues with the game: at times cumbersome controls, clipping through objects when trying to grapple things that aren't the intended solution, terrible combat with awful AI, the checkpoint system in place that only lets you restart in said designated checkpoints when the game really needs quicksaves or something similar to the reboot. All of this could be chalked up to lack of polish (even if it is supposed to be a remake....), but that really isn't the case. This game is flawed at its core. It is so god damn boring.If you don't like the first hour don't even bother going through the rest. It doesn't change one bit. Most of the mechanics are introduced up front, and the aforementioned issues will continue to knaw and knaw at you until you're throwing your hands up in frustration. There is absolutely nothing to break up the monotony. I liked what few cutscenes there were but they didn't hint at a real plot or anything. I managed to get through Peru with much struggling and the first part of the Greek tomb before getting tired of falling off and having to climb all the way back up again because the checkpoint was at the bottom of a huge pit.Don't buy this game. Don't buy this franchise for that matter.

content:
Posted: February 1
												Don't buy this game. No, really. Don't do it. I love Tomb Raider so much, but this is just one huge buggy pile of garbage. You get stuck EVERYWHERE on ledges and against objects. Lara's hair keeps having physics stretching problems snapping all over the screen. A lot of times you get so hung up on the world geometry that you just stand there clipping over and over until you quit the game because you can't do anything to get out of it. Then there's the camera. The camera snapping in this is one of the worst I've ever seen. No matter how you adjust things, it jerks and shakes enough to induce epilepsy. This came couldn't have been play tested, or the developers simply didn't care, because there's non stop buggyness no matter where and what level you're on. And forget the combat. It's clunky and terrible. You know how in old TR you used to be able to draw your guns and have her aim and keep on the enemy? Forget that. Now you lose track of them constantly and if you aren't rushing towards something trying to kill you (getting mauled in the process) you can't get a lock on them. Worst combat of a TR game ever. Don't buy it even if it's 3 bucks. The shaking camera, constant physics problems and general stress literally made me sick.

												I do not usually downvote a game but i could not stand this one more than 40 minutes. If you played tomb raiders through your childhood, you may find something interesting in this game. I played last 2 games, 2013 and rise of the tomb raider, and this one is nowhere near fun as much as those two.Ok, tomb raider is a legendary puzzle - advanture game. But here is what i see in this game, considering the last two games:Cons (since there are no pros):- This is not a survival game. Just a 3d puzzle game without any concept. Just making your way through some ancient places.- Even though this game is released in 2007, grapcially there are much better looking games than this.- Even on easy difficulty, there is an unexplainable combat system. Animals attack in close couters, you are trying to manuever your way out, desperately trying to shoot at the write angle. Ii tried combat modes, hold and toggle targeting modes and neither did make any sense.- There is no story to be a part of or embrace. Just learn how to make your way around and kinetic dynamics and go.- It might get a bit exciting in the next chapters, which i am not intended to see, but i haev never been this much bored.- Soundtrack is older than the games timeline.- The movement dynamics are causing cheap deaths.If you can enjoy a monotoneus puzzle solving game where you fight with the strangest combat system in the history, give this a try. I am a patient person and could not take it more than 40 minutes.

												The start of Lara's adventure.
