Posted: November 6, 2015
												Recommended if you like long periods of exploring large temples, ruins, etc., minimal gun actions, confusing/difficult puzzles (at least for me), sometimes less-than-stellar controls and camera anglesThis is my first Tomb Raider game I’ve completed. I only bought this on sale because I purchased the latest Tomb Raider game and thought that game after playing an hour or so was cool, so I wanted to experience some of the games before playing that reboot (as silly as that may sound).As this is my first Tomb Raider game, and understanding this is an HD remake of the original game with additional features I presume and not drastically making an entire new game, I still got what I expected. It’s a game about raiding tombs…So, even though this is a remake of an old game, it’s a game released in 2007, and I’m playing it in 2015 with my personal standards adjusted to somewhat compensate the difference.Story 5/10Lara Croft gets approached to find some artifact. After long levels of jumping, climbing, exploring, solving puzzles, you get a short cutscene. Sound 9/10Fitting music, with mystical/mysterious tones as well as the typical fast-paced stuff when things get heavy for Lara.Graphics 9/10For a game released in 2007 and a remake of an old game which had horrendous graphics (I lived through that age of heavy pixels) I was satisfied with what was presented in this game. The surrounding environment, in the temples and such were not unpleasant to look at.Gameplay 7.5/10As I mentioned that I never played any previous Tomb Raider games, I still knew what to expect since it was based on the older games. It’s 90% running around, pushing boxes, jumping, rolling, climbing, and/or solving puzzles. 10% using guns.Side note: I wonder why Lara has infinite ammo for her starting pistols? And this is eventually relevant to the story in the final boss fight which made me chuckle, you’ll find out if you get there.-Jumping and rolling is cool, as Lara is acrobatic so she can do flips or a handspring. Also, for jumping onto far ledges you might lose your grip and have to press E to fix it, so that’s a cool addition to the genre of platforming games. When the opportunity is present, you can use your grappling hook to run across walls or swing across a room, though the controls combined with the camera angle made it annoying sometimes to jump to where you wanted to go.-Additionally with camera angles, they were sometimes annoying during climbing. E.g. you’re on a ledge, and you may need to jump to behind you (180 degrees). But sometimes I didn’t know that beforehand, so while you’re hanging on a ledge, the camera can’t move to see behind you for some reason.-As for guns, you get a few additional weapons that you discover. What’s cool is the rare enemies you do actually face, is the dodging move, where time slows down a bit and if you time it right you can deliver a critical hit after rolling out of the way.-Targeting multiple enemies is a bit of a pain. The rare time there are multiple enemies that can give you trouble, perhaps I just missed what proper way to do so, but I was using my mouse to switch targets but it is not a smooth transition at all, almost unresponsive at times.-Some puzzles and proper routes felt challenging, at least for me. I ended up looking at video walkthroughs many, many times to avoid wasting time. I’m a crappy tomb raider.-Sometimes controls feel shtty, this is probably the top two gripes I have with the game (the first being a lack of action/gun play). Jumping and reaching where you want to go is not as easy and smooth as I would like (It doesn’t happen every time, but it’s something that definitely negatively affects the experience). I probably swore more times from missing jumps than any other game I’ve every played.There was even one point, climbing up the same ladder, I pressed the same controls to jump (as I did successfully did before) but it wouldn’t let me reach the ledge. I ended up jumping onto a wall and then falling, taking some damage. This is definitely more annoying than the Assassin’s Creed games.All in all, I have mixed emotions on finally completing this game. I’m happy to finally complete a tomb raider experience cuz it has spawned so many games. On the other hand, this game is not one I will probably ever play again. I have no desire to touch Croft Manor, whatever extra gameplay it offers aside from story mode.Overall score for me is 7.5/10If I was a gazillionaire, I'd offer a million dollars to anyone who hasn't played the game before to beat this game (with the assist of a video walkthrough) with only ten lives. That's how frustruated I was at times with the controls resulting in many, many falls to my death.

Posted: February 13, 2014
												I played this game first on PS2. PS2. My god. That is so weird.This is an excellent adaptation of both the games, and the character. I feel like this Lara is closer to the Lara I wanted to see when the first game came out. She's kind of cold and distant, maybe a little aristocratic, almost. I've heard a lot of people complain about how she seems too "angry" and that she's not "flirty" with Larsen anymore. Those people are dumb. Lara is much more appealing and much more interesting when she's not whatever the scene needs to her to be; Lara is consistent in Anniversary, as a character, and as a person. Her character builds and changes throughout the game, rather than being a static mouthpiece for the original writers to act out childish, sexist fantasies. This may not be a character we always like--she's like an antihero in that way--but we can always empathize with her, because she's more human when she has flaws.The gameplay is fantastic, the game is solidly built/programmed--I've never encountered a glitch in this game, and I must have played it on my PS2 through at least 3 or more times. The game is also beautiful, even if, much like in the first game, it suffers from inconsistent lighting and sometimes a wonky camera.

Posted: December 1, 2015
												(Skip below to TL;DR if you don't want to read the whole review)Plot:The plot is really interesting. I like it. I like how they incorporated Atlantis into the game's story. I'm a real sucker for stories about "lost cities" like Atlantis, so as expected, I really enjoyed the story of the game. Atlhough, I was a little bit disappointed since there aren't really that much cutscenes in the game. I feel like most of the game is spent solving puzzles and fighting enemies. This makes me feel a little bit unsatisfied because it felt like the game's story was short. However, it's a good story nonetheless. Difficulty:There are two things I wanna talk about in this part. Puzzle and enemies.  Puzzles: The puzzle part of the game is really well done. In terms of difficulty, I don't think puzzles in this game are very hard. They just require you to think. This is one of the things that I really like in this game. Some of the puzzles in this game were too complex that I actually struggled on some of them, and I actually like it. I like that feeling you get when you actually solve a really hard puzzle. It feels rewarding. The best part about puzzles in this game is that you don't even get a single hint on what to do when you're hit with one.   Enemies:Enemies in this game aren't really that hard to beat. Although, I really find them annoying sometimes. When you get knocked down by one of their attacks, they probably will hit you by the same attack again as you're getting up which will knock you back down. This is really annoying especially when you're fighting flying enemies on a ledge high above the ground or above a pool of lava. You could actually fall down because they're just continuously doing their blast attack on you which pushes you off the ledge. Controls: For the most part controls are okay. I do find some things annoying. First of all, targeting is sometimes annoying. When you're fighting moving enemies, especially flying enemies, the camera will lose focus and make you aim at thin air or something you don't even want to aim at.Second, camera in this game isn't that good. Sometimes when you're doing puzzles that require jumping (walls, ledges, pole, etc.), the camera will completely fail you and will cause you to jump at the wrong direction, and if you're jumping from a really high place, this will cause you to die. I died so many times at puzzles and places that I wasn't even supposed to die at because of this.Graphics: This game came out in 2007 so it's understandable that it can't compare to the graphics of games nowadays. I can say, however, that this game's graphics is really good considering the time of its release. I mean, even now, compared to the games nowadays, this game's graphics isn't that bad.TL;DR (Overall):I think this game is really well-done. The story is really amazing. However, this game has a lot of puzzles that you must solve. A good number of them are, in my opinion, so complex, that you may want to look up a walkthrough online. Controls are good for the most part, but can be annoying at times. Graphics aren't that bad compared to the games nowadays. I do recommend people to play this game because it's really fun and enjoying to play.I rate this game 8/10

Posted: March 20
												I generally enjoyed the game, but there were some infuriating moments that make me never want to play this again. It's long enough, but hours upon hours were spent to achieve the 3 wall runs that gave most people nightmares, so playtime is not accurate. The story is interesting (with alternative reality geography, but it's a game, I guess?...) and there are some surprise story elements that add to the experience.I HATE wall running and I positively ABHOR wall running with timed elements, and especially in the Lost Pyramid the predictability of Lara moving towards the spot you want her to is probably based on lunar eclipses and Mercury's position relative to your zodiac sign, because for the life of me I have no idea why and how I managed to finish some levels. Have your blood pressure pills close by.I think the developers decided to make a game that was difficult for the sake of being difficult and forgot to factor in the enjoyability aspect.  I play games to have fun, not to be annoyed. Don't feel guilty if you use alternate methods to skip some checkpoints.The most enjoyable parts included Boss fights (I loved all of them, especially the different ways you have to find to battle each Boss) and long sequences of accurate jumps and holds accompanied by practical puzzles, basically the reasons why I love TR games.It works nicely with a controller on Win 10. Advice: When wall running, use keyboard R-L arrows for movements and the controller for all the rest.

Posted: January 2, 2014
												After the infamous Tomb Raider: Angel of Darkness, the Tomb Raider reins were handed off to Crystal Dynamics, who brought us the Legacy of Kain Series. This spawned a trilogy consisting of: Legend, Anniversary, and Underworld as well as the spin-off (Lara Croft and the Guardian of Light) and the 2013 reboot that Square Enix published.Anniversary is the second game released after AoD and is arguably the best of the aforementioned trilogy. Legend had some graphical issues (such as a bug that causes the game to crash when "Next Generation Content" is enabled in the graphics options), some shoddy combat, and lacked a strong challenge. Underworld had a camera that hated you, and weaker platforming compared the the other two games.Anniversary (a re-imagining of the original Tomb Raider from 1996) improves upon Legend's foundation and fixes a lot of its issues. The levels are somewhat linear (especially compared to the open levels in Underworld, which actually worked against them in a way), but they offer solid platforming that challenges you because they're challenging, and not because Lara refuses to grab something (Legend) or because the camera is a sociopath (Underworld) or because it's ocassionally difficult to tell what can be grabbed onto (Underworld, again). If you die, it's because you ♥♥♥♥ed up, not because Lara suddenly had a minor brain aneurysm. If you only play one Tomb Raider game, this one's your most solid choice (at least amongst the Crystal Dynamics games). Even at full price, it's a solid deal.

Posted: January 28, 2014
												This game is one of the best games I ever played! And being a Tomb Raider Game, it has it's challenges.Being a remake of the original Tomb Raider I, this game is basically the same as Tomb Raider I, but with a few extra twists and turns in the life of Lara Croft and with updated sound, graphics, music, and puzzles.If you are familiar with any of the older Tomb Raider Games (From the original Tomb Raider I up to Tomb Raider Chronicles) then you should buy and play this game for sure! You won't be able to stop until you finish the game!And even after you finish the game, you'll feel inclined to play it again or maybe show somebody else whom you know the ropes of this game. The game is quite challenging and the levels are very life-like as are the sound effects, the enemies you encounter, the puzzles you'll have to solve, and the overall environment.One part of the game was so challenging, I actually had to cheat in order to complete it!In short, if you're an avid Tomb Raider fan, you will NOT be disappointed if you play this game. You may feel frustrated and you may feel inclined to cheat or skip a level, but you won't be disappointed. And there are plenty of guides and walk throughs online to help you complete the game.Also, if you're skilled at third-person combat (Like me) then you will probably be able to defeat most of the enemies in the game with little to no trouble. I was able to defeat the final boss using only pistols!If you don't believe me, just try the demo of this game or buy it and see for yourself!

Posted: January 1, 2015
												A reimagining of the orginal Tomb Raider and so awesome!Graphics:While the game does have slighty above PS2-era graphics, they do look quite nice on PC.  Animations for Lara and npcs and enemies look good, if a little stilted at times.  While skies in outdoor levels look not so good, the levels themselves look nice and detailed.  I also liked the water effects, even though the water seemed to always be tinted green.  My only issues are with the screen settings.  It seems that only certain Hz settings lag the game and in some areas, there is a HUGE amount of screen tearing, to the point that it dissoriented me.Sound:The music had some good tracks, but most were bland or repeated often, mainly the enemy encounter music.  The guns sounds lacked impact, therefor feeling like peashooters rather than high calibre weapons.  The voice acting was decent enough, but some voices seemed hammed, (like the gangsta boy the main villian sics on you).Control:Despite the fact that you can use a controller for this game, it will only show keyboard controls, leading you to take a few minutes of random button presses to fgure the controls out, though you figure it out after awhile.  Controls also seemed a little laggy at times, making it hard to make pixel-perfect timed jumps.  Lara also seems stiff and slow to respond.Gameplay:I have to admit that while I really don't like platformers or platforming puzzles, I did enjoy playing this game.  The puzzles  are diffuclt, but still beatable for an idiot like me, with practise.  Checkpoints are sacttered well enough to reduce frustration when dying to a jump or puzzle, though that won't stop players like from still getting frustrated from dying 10 times to the same thing.  The levels are also filled with hidden areas with health items, ammo and guns to use.  Combat relies on locking on to enemies and dodging at the right time to get a single killshot on enemies.  The dodge tackes practise, but it will ultimately save a lot of ammo in the end.  Boss fights consist of filling it's rage meter and then some trick to hurt them (making them run into walls, shoot each other, etc).  The story, an expanded retelling of the first game, has a few slow parts, but very nicely picks up in the last half.If you like/love the Tomb Raider series, this is a VERY good entry to the series and also a good starting point for anyone looking to get into the series.

Though if you want a game that is pretty much challenging as in a certain strategy to beat a boss; This remake does that job particularly well.Some of the Music is damned great and a badass intensity for some bosses. Some pieces are remade that the first Tomb Raider player would definitely recognize. Specifically the Centaurs Boss theme. Yes. That song rocks like hell.The level design feels far more shorter in comparison to the original.. In a way some levels feel like they practically merged together [I played the original so I can tell the differences between the two] though the puzzles can be really difficult to some others though I beaten this game before so I can't say it feels a first time deal.The bugs? Well mostly doesn't appear much but you do have small times where it just glitches on you or you cannot grab no matter how close you are. I would never recommend playing this game on PC. The Console versions are more fixed than this despite the graphics are great for the most part on the PC but the gameplay could use a little fix then it's all set for good.Either way; Yes I do recommend this game but be prepared for some bugs in the game.. This is all I have to say for this one.

Posted: January 1, 2015
												A reimagining of the orginal Tomb Raider and so awesome!Graphics:While the game does have slighty above PS2-era graphics, they do look quite nice on PC.  Animations for Lara and npcs and enemies look good, if a little stilted at times.  While skies in outdoor levels look not so good, the levels themselves look nice and detailed.  I also liked the water effects, even though the water seemed to always be tinted green.  My only issues are with the screen settings.  It seems that only certain Hz settings lag the game and in some areas, there is a HUGE amount of screen tearing, to the point that it dissoriented me.Sound:The music had some good tracks, but most were bland or repeated often, mainly the enemy encounter music.  The guns sounds lacked impact, therefor feeling like peashooters rather than high calibre weapons.  The voice acting was decent enough, but some voices seemed hammed, (like the gangsta boy the main villian sics on you).Control:Despite the fact that you can use a controller for this game, it will only show keyboard controls, leading you to take a few minutes of random button presses to fgure the controls out, though you figure it out after awhile.  Controls also seemed a little laggy at times, making it hard to make pixel-perfect timed jumps.  Lara also seems stiff and slow to respond.Gameplay:I have to admit that while I really don't like platformers or platforming puzzles, I did enjoy playing this game.  The puzzles  are diffuclt, but still beatable for an idiot like me, with practise.  Checkpoints are sacttered well enough to reduce frustration when dying to a jump or puzzle, though that won't stop players like from still getting frustrated from dying 10 times to the same thing.  The levels are also filled with hidden areas with health items, ammo and guns to use.  Combat relies on locking on to enemies and dodging at the right time to get a single killshot on enemies.  The dodge tackes practise, but it will ultimately save a lot of ammo in the end.  Boss fights consist of filling it's rage meter and then some trick to hurt them (making them run into walls, shoot each other, etc).  The story, an expanded retelling of the first game, has a few slow parts, but very nicely picks up in the last half.If you like/love the Tomb Raider series, this is a VERY good entry to the series and also a good starting point for anyone looking to get into the series.

												10/10 would make dinosaurs extinct againI loved the original tomb raider game on the PSX, and i still think the story was the best tomb raider had ever done. the whole atlantis ancient genetic engineering experiment gone wrong was brilliant.i still remember  being awed by the valley of the dinosaurs the first time. i still remember the sense of vertigo when you have to navigate a massive vertical shaft in the tomb of St Francis. I still remember the terror when you navigate the deadly traps of the tomb of Tihocan only to be confronted by 2 fireball hurling 10 foot tall meat centaurs right outside the gates to the goal.i still remember the sense of awe when you find the sanctuary of the scion is a gigantic Sphynx statue that you have to open.i lay awake at night thinking of the creepy coridors of the great pyramid of atlantis, whose walls pulsed with blood and veins and i cry myself to sleep thinking of the gigantic meat monster that on more than one ocassion picked me up in its fist and slammed me against the deck like an oversised toddler having a temper tantrum or hurling me half a mile down the central shaft of the said pyramid, only to land in a lake of magma.and this is the 1997 original, Aniversary has all these moments with modern updated graphics, the game has lost none of the sense of dread and actually builds on the 1997 original, this is a prime example of how remakes should be done: Properly

Posted: October 23, 2015
												+    :1) atmosphere2) music3) puzzles4) traditional Tomb Raider controls without excessive additions (pseudo prakour, action camera, not necessary animations)5) great story6) feels exactly like you are playing those old TRs.-     :1) not really calibrated checkpoints (or completion conditions) which sometimes can cause early "level completion" which can ruin your artifact hunt (because even if you go back and grab some artifact it won't be considered as "found" so you have to start the entire level to complete that). But this one is not completely negative feature since this game has alot of reasons to complete it again.2) rare bugs. Like idling T-Rex.3) overextended and high number of fight scenes closer to the end of the game.Overall, this game is a great adventure which consumes you totally, especially if you are a fan of old Lara Croft games. It's like watching Indiana Jones movies with all its charm and charisma. The music and sound make this even more atmoshperic and bring alot of nostalgia. Sometimes I had the feeling that some puzzles should be slightly harder to complete cos their completion is obvious if you pay attention to paths you can go just by looking around.Greece and Egypt locations are the best at my opinion because they are really thought out and extremely atmospheric. Croft Manor is just right behind them so Peru and the last one (no spoilers) are at the end of this chart because they are not so exciting but that doesn't mean they are bad.Anyways, highly recommend this game for anyone and for those who played PS1 Tomb Raiders this game is "must have".

Posted: January 2, 2014
												After the infamous Tomb Raider: Angel of Darkness, the Tomb Raider reins were handed off to Crystal Dynamics, who brought us the Legacy of Kain Series. This spawned a trilogy consisting of: Legend, Anniversary, and Underworld as well as the spin-off (Lara Croft and the Guardian of Light) and the 2013 reboot that Square Enix published.Anniversary is the second game released after AoD and is arguably the best of the aforementioned trilogy. Legend had some graphical issues (such as a bug that causes the game to crash when "Next Generation Content" is enabled in the graphics options), some shoddy combat, and lacked a strong challenge. Underworld had a camera that hated you, and weaker platforming compared the the other two games.Anniversary (a re-imagining of the original Tomb Raider from 1996) improves upon Legend's foundation and fixes a lot of its issues. The levels are somewhat linear (especially compared to the open levels in Underworld, which actually worked against them in a way), but they offer solid platforming that challenges you because they're challenging, and not because Lara refuses to grab something (Legend) or because the camera is a sociopath (Underworld) or because it's ocassionally difficult to tell what can be grabbed onto (Underworld, again). If you die, it's because you ♥♥♥♥ed up, not because Lara suddenly had a minor brain aneurysm. If you only play one Tomb Raider game, this one's your most solid choice (at least amongst the Crystal Dynamics games). Even at full price, it's a solid deal.

Posted: February 16, 2014
												Tomb Raider: Anniversary is a hard game to recommend. If you only have vague memories of the original or are otherwise unfamiliar with Lara Croft's first adventure, Anniversary is a good game to play but maybe not play to completion. Even though it updated and rebooted Tomb Raider 1's brick like controls, there are still elements from its pre Assassin's Creed and Uncharted control scheme that are maddening. Those games made games with traversal mechanics look and control easily, but Tomb Raider is not as up to par.The climbing and jumping controls are never as tight as you want them to be and work perhaps 85 to 90% of the time. There are repeated instances I encountered where Lara failed to grab ledges after walking off of them, and also ledges she didn't grab after a death defying leap that did in fact result in her death. The controls orient to the direction that the camera is facing, and in a game where you have control of the camera all the time, it can make it almost impossible to figure out the proper direction you need to press a button to make Lara go. Ever pressed up on your controller and seen a person climb DOWN a ladder? It happened to me. Twice. To say nothing of jumping off a swinging rope in the wrong direction repeatedly. Some sections seemed engineered to raise blood pressure.Imperfect as it is, Anniversary does capture a feeling I felt missing in the latest gritty Tomb Raider reboot, namely that I was traversing ancient, labyrinth-like tombs with treasure to be had instead of an open world action game. Basically, there were no real 'tombs' in the new Tomb Raider, but this captured that feeling perfectly. The homages to the original game found here are a lot of fun, right down to the cutscenes. Some of the new boss fights can be a tad infuriating but are mostly a snap once you get Lara's new adrenaline dodging down pat. I still miss the original's T-Rex fight, but I can understand why they'd want to update it. Killing a giant dinosaur with only a pair of small handguns doesn't sound realistic, but what about this game should be? Also, making the in-game commentary markers look like the old save crystals was a nice touch.You may not reach the end if you don't have the patience for the controls, which I know I don't, but even then I think this game is still a good Tomb Raider game even in its imperfect state. I just wish that Crystal Dynamics had gotten their controls right for this game instead of waiting a few years to nail the controls for Lara's Tomb Raider reboot. Worth catching on sale, but be prepared for lots of cursing during the more technical bits.

Posted: February 13, 2014
												I played this game first on PS2. PS2. My god. That is so weird.This is an excellent adaptation of both the games, and the character. I feel like this Lara is closer to the Lara I wanted to see when the first game came out. She's kind of cold and distant, maybe a little aristocratic, almost. I've heard a lot of people complain about how she seems too "angry" and that she's not "flirty" with Larsen anymore. Those people are dumb. Lara is much more appealing and much more interesting when she's not whatever the scene needs to her to be; Lara is consistent in Anniversary, as a character, and as a person. Her character builds and changes throughout the game, rather than being a static mouthpiece for the original writers to act out childish, sexist fantasies. This may not be a character we always like--she's like an antihero in that way--but we can always empathize with her, because she's more human when she has flaws.The gameplay is fantastic, the game is solidly built/programmed--I've never encountered a glitch in this game, and I must have played it on my PS2 through at least 3 or more times. The game is also beautiful, even if, much like in the first game, it suffers from inconsistent lighting and sometimes a wonky camera.

												This is a remake of the 1996 original, and is probably the best starting point in the series for a newcomer. The controls are fluid and responsive, and the levels are detailed and intricate. You can just dive deep into the tombs, but the game rewards exploration by giving you relics and artifacts to find. The improved graphics look nice, despite some low-polygon models and the awkward ragdoll effect when Lara dies. The game freely distributes checkpoints and you can save anywhere, so dying a lot on some of the tricker jumps or puzzles isn't very punishing. Great 3D platformer with perfect level design.

Posted: January 21, 2014
												Yet another installment of the Tomb Raider series, but this one is quite special because is the remake of the first game using the Tomb Raider Legend engine (quite frankly, I was not aware of this, but found out after I finished the game, because never played the first of the series... XD). If you played Tomb Raider: Legend you will have an idea about the controls and how everything work, like using the grapple hook, Lara's moves and the weapons system is pretty much the same. There is a lot of collectibles per stage and if you find all of them you will unlock stuff, like Lara's costumes and stuff. I'm assuming the story is pretty much the same as the first game, since this is a remake; quite good, follows the pattern of the whole series(tomb exploring, relic finding, weird stuff happening, etc). You can even play the Croft's Manor where you are pretty much in Lara's house, where you can spend some time wondering around and even in this mission there is stuff to find and discover the secrets of the Croft Manor. If you are looking for an old school game where you have to explore tombs without lots of signs where you have to go or do, this is definitely the game for you!...

Posted: January 28, 2014
												This game is one of the best games I ever played! And being a Tomb Raider Game, it has it's challenges.Being a remake of the original Tomb Raider I, this game is basically the same as Tomb Raider I, but with a few extra twists and turns in the life of Lara Croft and with updated sound, graphics, music, and puzzles.If you are familiar with any of the older Tomb Raider Games (From the original Tomb Raider I up to Tomb Raider Chronicles) then you should buy and play this game for sure! You won't be able to stop until you finish the game!And even after you finish the game, you'll feel inclined to play it again or maybe show somebody else whom you know the ropes of this game. The game is quite challenging and the levels are very life-like as are the sound effects, the enemies you encounter, the puzzles you'll have to solve, and the overall environment.One part of the game was so challenging, I actually had to cheat in order to complete it!In short, if you're an avid Tomb Raider fan, you will NOT be disappointed if you play this game. You may feel frustrated and you may feel inclined to cheat or skip a level, but you won't be disappointed. And there are plenty of guides and walk throughs online to help you complete the game.Also, if you're skilled at third-person combat (Like me) then you will probably be able to defeat most of the enemies in the game with little to no trouble. I was able to defeat the final boss using only pistols!If you don't believe me, just try the demo of this game or buy it and see for yourself!

Posted: December 21, 2013
												If you are going to play just one Tomb Raider game, this should be it. Certain elements of the story were changed in order to fit the Legends story arc. Graphic wise the environments look pretty decent for such an old game and the scenery is still captivating. The characters look cartoony, personally I prefer it over the more realistic Lara in the 2013 reboot. The gameplay is closer to the original games with a focus on exploration and puzzle solving instead of action and combat as the aforementioned reboot. During the later levels it feels like the developers got a bit lazy and decided to focus on time based puzzles rather than complicated ones. I found the levels in the second World to be the most interesting of all. I encountered some minor bugs but it wasn't anything game breaking. This is a great a buy for its price.

Posted: October 3, 2015
												I can't specify it's accuracy to the original but I can say it feels like an old game made new. It still has an atmosphere of something different; traversing the terrain is a puzzle but an immensely satisfying one and modern game design has taken off some of the really rough edges. Lara too feels different to the weird creature used as a marketing tool: She is predominantly silent in this outing and very acrobatic, but instead of feeling like she exists to be objectified there is a sense of purpose in how she climbs and leaps from place to place. It's hard to fully explain but when she pulls herself up a high ledge it feels like I am controlling a determined gymnast and in some sense I feel I am there, showing that strength and dexterity. In those moments I get a sense of just why the original tomb raider was such a hit.

Posted: September 28, 2015
												10/10 would make dinosaurs extinct againI loved the original tomb raider game on the PSX, and i still think the story was the best tomb raider had ever done. the whole atlantis ancient genetic engineering experiment gone wrong was brilliant.i still remember  being awed by the valley of the dinosaurs the first time. i still remember the sense of vertigo when you have to navigate a massive vertical shaft in the tomb of St Francis. I still remember the terror when you navigate the deadly traps of the tomb of Tihocan only to be confronted by 2 fireball hurling 10 foot tall meat centaurs right outside the gates to the goal.i still remember the sense of awe when you find the sanctuary of the scion is a gigantic Sphynx statue that you have to open.i lay awake at night thinking of the creepy coridors of the great pyramid of atlantis, whose walls pulsed with blood and veins and i cry myself to sleep thinking of the gigantic meat monster that on more than one ocassion picked me up in its fist and slammed me against the deck like an oversised toddler having a temper tantrum or hurling me half a mile down the central shaft of the said pyramid, only to land in a lake of magma.and this is the 1997 original, Aniversary has all these moments with modern updated graphics, the game has lost none of the sense of dread and actually builds on the 1997 original, this is a prime example of how remakes should be done: Properly

Posted: December 3, 2013
												Tomb Raider: Anniversary is a more modern remake of the first Tomb Raider, and it plays fairly well. Unlike TR: Legend there is not a huge focus on the combat, it's mainly just platforming with the odd fights here and there. There are several unique zones to explore. The platforming and puzzles are good, and some of them are rather challenging at times. However, there were many times where bugs made the game irritating. Certain places where you couldn't see where you were jumping, not jumping in exactly the right way, and some other issues. They are easy enough to look over, except the ones that make the puzzles infuriating to solve, and the rest of the experience more than makes up for it. One final thing is that there isn't a lot of ambience in the zones. That may be fine with you but I didn't care for it.

Posted: December 3, 2014
												A major imrovement over Legend. Anniversary is much more challenging (on HARD), better unlockables is another, and it's a longer game. It's pretty much a faithful reimagining of the original game with maybe a few sacrifices here and there, but overall it feels fresh. Personally, I recommend Anniversary over Legend and Underworld. It offers way more replay value than the other two in Crystal Dynamics' classic trilogy. The only downsides are pretty minor. For example, there is NO BLOOD (even the original had blood), which looks rather silly given the fact that TR relies on realistic environments and animals. Also, the death scenes have been toned down and use cheesy, but amusing ragdoll effects. The original had better death sequences and even had blood. Also, there seems to be some camera issues here and there that will have Lara falling to her doom (via cheesy ragdoll physics). Other than that Anniversary is probably the best of the lot in the LAU trio. Pick it up!

Posted: December 3, 2014
												Man, I remember playing Tomb Raider on PC back in 1997 at a friend's house. It was pretty impressive, but it was super hard to control. I hated the controls so much. I tried it with a joystick and that wasn't really any better. I spent most of my time being killed by various animals and accidentally falling off of stuff. And watching Lara Croft's low-polygon butt move as she walked, and noting that she was very pointy and sharp in many places.This 2007 remake of the game is so much better. It still has a few minor issues with the camera running into walls and difficulty seeing where you are jumping when you're hanging off a cliff face and jumping behind you, but I guess that's just part of the game... But the controls are standardized, the graphics are much better, the game is much more enjoyable. Steam is asking "Do you recommend this game?" Yeah, yeah I do. It's a pretty good game. I enjoy this game.

Posted: December 24, 2010
												Although frustrating at times with the puzzles, this game is fantastic.  The puzzles are often fairly obvious, but the challenging ones can entertain or frustrate for hours depending on your tolerance.  I finished this game in about 19 hours total playtime over the course of a couple weeks.  If you have enjoyed previous games in the series this one is quite similar but with newer graphics and physics capabilities.Be warned though, save your game often as there are a number of bugs.  I played through a particularly difficult part of the game only to end up finding that I got stuck later on and had to reload a save that was before the difficult part.  Needless to say this was annoying.  I suggest a save after most checkpoints, or at least major events, especially in the end during the "tower ascent" portion, there I would say save at every checkpoint and don't overwrite any saves, you never know how far you may have to go back.

Posted: March 27, 2016
												Tomb Raider needs no introduction, it was a popular franchise back in the 90s, even if the gameplay of old was very difficult to get into.  When I was a child, I found the original series quite troublesome to play despite the core idea of solving intricate temple puzzles and exploring the uninhabited ancient tombs to be quite intriguing.  This reboot, reimagining, whatever you want to call it, though some may say remakes/-boots are becoming the norm and somewhat tiresome, despite it's flaws is still a somewhat welcome entry in the series.  It modernizes certain aspects and puts a new sheen on what I even thought was an ugly franchise back in the 90s.The game knows exactly what it is, and recreates the PS1 FMVs and levels from 1995 with almost exact precision.  The FMVs of old were re-imagined in the in-game engine.  It is nostalgic to remember the cutscenes from '95, and how they were presented in pretty much the exact way.  It shows that Crystal Dynamics have paid attention to their source material in certain ways.  In saying that, it shows what this game was for -- the oldschool Tomb Raider fans.  I wasn't a HUGE Tomb Raider fan back in the 90s, but I enjoyed playing for how little I'd progress in them.  But since the reboot in 2013, I've become somewhat more of a fan, digging back into these reimaginings after finishing 2013 TR.At any rate, the visuals are VERY passable.  This was made for the PS2/XBox generation, and in certain areas it shows, but it's very fitting.  The visuals uphold a certain style that can be considered timeless.  The environments and characters unify a certain style Crystal Dynamics was going for, and it probably could stand the test of time.  There are jaggies even under certain Anti-Aliasing settings, but the game certainly is not ugly.  The environments are colorful and presented very well, and all the levels have a distinct and interesting theme.The "timlessness" vibe of the visuals also brings me to remember how cumbersome the controls and general TR game mechanics were back in the day.  In the PS1 games, the gameplay engine operated on a grid system -- which could be well seen through the outdated visuals, you could literally see textures cut off on the ground to show the grid on which Lara would operate.  In Anniversary, it's non-existent, but the climbing reminisces the difficult jumping of old.  Traversing cliff faces and making jumps can prove to be quite difficult and no matter your skill there will be times where you will die.  Either from the engine deciding to not let Lara grapple, or what I liked to call a "hard-coded" jump that is only made if certain placements or conditions are met.  There are times when it seems like the engine just says "nope" whenever you try to make a jump and she either falls short somehow, or decides not to grapple a ledge, no matter how HARD one can be mooshing down that grab button.I played with a mouse and keyboard, so that's pretty much why my pinky is so tired.  Using mouse for looking around is just a preference of mine, and I probably would've had a better time on pad, if I didn't use mouse-aiming for certain precise jumps.  You don't really ever have to aim to fire at enemies; there's auto-targetting reticules for that.  I used the mouse more for aiming my jumps than anything, and it seemed to help a bit in that department, even if my pinky (holding Ctrl) for grappling will probably help in developing carpal tunnel.  Some of the grapple hook segments can be wonky too.  So if you decide to play this game, be patient, get to know Lara's height and jump limits.  The game recreates a lot of the original's levels and cutscenes almost faithfully, and with a few twists -- for example, the T-Rex segment in the third stage has you fend off raptors before the beast himself stomps into the fray.  What's noteworthy (and may be eye-rolling to some) about big bosses throughout the game, is that you're presented with a "dodge-and-fire mechanic" in which you use to bring beasts into a wall, spikes, and so on.  It's a welcome addition to progress through the game, because I sucked combat in Tomb Raider as a kid and would die a LOT on boss segments.  Also most of the human-sized bosses have been boiled down to QTEs, which I don't have a problem with, they're to-the-point and are responsive, so it's just kind of a "whatever" kinda thing.  It doesn't pull a Bayonetta or God of War thing where you may miss a one-second response time -- time slows down and gives you ample opportunity to press it.  And with the context of the cutscenes, you shouldn't have a problem distinguishing which will have a QTE or not.As mentioned, the game was developed for any TR fans that still existed for the time, with a more modern approach.  And certainly the climbing, jumping, and grapple hook segments proved to be very irritating at times.  Very late segments in the game were timed and you had to be precise with almost every button press or into the lava I would go.  But overall, satisfaction is still left after completing stages and the game, and there are collectibles and unlocks for any player willing enough to 100% such as outfits, artwork, commentary and so forth.I'd recommend even if you aren't a die-hard fan of Tomb Raider.  Though infuriating at times, the game gets more flack than is really deserved.  I certainly swore a couple times, but it's by no-means a punishing game.  Crystal Dynamics seemed to put love into this game, and tried to put a new formula to a dead grid-based exploration game.  Whether you choose pad or k+m, it's just a preference, because I'm sure no matter what you pick, certain fingers of yours will be tired.  Even still, give it a go if you're curious.

Posted: January 5, 2016
												WARNING: DO NOT BUY THIS GAME AS YOUR FIRST TR GAME, BECAUSE IT WILL MAKE YOU ANNOYED A LOTGameplay: Same as Legend, but with a couple enhancements. Even though I recommend this game, only fans of TR series that played other TR games before should buy it. Out of old Crystal Dynamics trilogy, this one has the hardest puzzles, most annoying platforming and the worst checkpoint system. It's a remake of first TR game, so it shares a lot of the puzzles (although reworked in most cases) and more or less same layout (though the levels are much bigger and some parts were reworked completely). The levels mostly consist of three or four parts, with most of them using same type of puzzles: get into a central room, find three or four keys in big side rooms, get back there and open door to get to next level. The platforming, as fun it could be is annoying because of checkpoint system that are not near so if you die or  mess up a jump, you're gonna backtrack a loong way to get where you fell from.On the other hand, the levels are diverse and look really good. On the other hand, because of the "find 3-4 keys to progress" mechanic in almost every level, the game is not as linear. The puzzles are a lot harder than Legend and even Underworld and it takes a while to see what you're supposed to do (which is fine, it's challenging)The controls are the same as Legend, but in some parts I felt frustrated because Lara sometimes doesn't exactly do what you want her to do, mainly because of the camera, which makes you take leaps of faith a lot.Combat is not as fun as it was in Legend. Lara only has to battle animals and mutants, so most of the time you just gun them down while dodging like crazy and when they get in "rage" state, they run to Lara and you kill them with a little QTE.Boss fights are fun, with each of them having a mechanic you need to make us of.Sound: It's good, although I liked Legend's more. It makes you more immersed and the enemies themes are my favourites.Story: Since it's a remake of first TR, the story is really basic. You get a cutscene at the beginning of a new level and that's mostly it. It's mostly about Lara being alone in the tombs, so don't expect it to be more like Legend.Technical: Looks a bit better than Legend. The locations are beautiful and detailed. As with Legend, it's impossible to make the game show on screen prompts for controller, but it works.Overall: Good for TR fans, annoying for others. Buy this at your own risk, but it can be fun when you like adventure puzzle style in games, this game is for you. Out of this trilogy, I enjoyed this one the least, mainly because the story takes the backseat and some parts of this game are really, really annoying.7,5/10

Posted: October 2, 2016
												Well, I've been going back and playing a ton of games that I've never played before and said whether I liked them or not. I figured it'd be high time to take a trip on the nostalgia train and talk about an old favorite from my childhood again.Obviously, Tomb Raider: Anniversary stands out a bit from Pajama Sam and Freddi Fish. I remember picking it up as my first Tomb Raider game, and it clearly had the virgin effect on me. However, going back to play TRA again has been a slightly different experience. It's been a good one, don't you worry.See, the first few Tomb Raider games by CORE have yet to astound me. I played about 3 hours of the 1996 original and the slow platforming and movement didn't do much for me and I'm still trying to will myself to play Tomb Raider Chronicles after an hour and a half that felt like more of the same. With Tomb Raider: Anniversary, Eidos took the slower, clunkier Lara Croft from TR I-VI and made her more agile and quick on her feet. But that's not the ONLY reason this game is good.I looked at some IGN and Gamespot reviews that ragged on the game's graphics and compared it to God of War II ("What a wonder of art that game was," I noted sarcastically), but I feel like even though Anniversary's graphics aren't the greatest... they're still utilized extremely well.See, any game can have great graphics, but they come and go with new software engines. Tomb Raider: Anniversary has some real weight to its environments. Ancient mausoleums, colliseums, and other-can't-see-ums are built like massive wonders that- when compared to the feeble size of Lara- give a sense of tremendous awe and a feeling of scale I haven't felt since I played Shadow of the Colossus.Anniversary has also got some great pacing between its action sequences, puzzles, and bosses. It doesn't just throw everything at you to digest in a linear fashion, like Legend. You have to take you time and soak up the experience slowly. Every time you solve a puzzle, you walk through a long tunnel or great expanse of land and feel the weight and time sinking into the lost worlds you uncover.Of course, you shouldn't expect me to talk about what I loved about this game forever. Time hasn't served Anniversary well. The shadows in the game are the game's biggest offenders. And the camera is a strong second! There are several times where the camera just would line up (or the game's shoddy lock-on system wouldn't properly lock onto the enemy that was directly in front of me) and I ended up dying because I didn't see a ledge right in front of me. That and the AI isn't the greatest. Some enemies will get stuck in walls or keep running into a ledge you're standing on while you lay waste to them.And the story is also kind of meh. It's your average Indiana Jones inspired adventure story, but without any unique flavor to it. Pretty much all the characters are simple stereotypes, and even though Lara is given a very rushed arc with her getting used to kill living people (a fact she already accepted by killing hundreds of humans in Legend, by the way), but beyond that she's just kind of there. There's no big twists or anything really gunning for you to get to the end... well, except for the wonderful environments.Tomb Raider: Anniversay isn't as polished as when I grew up with it, but I'd still recommend it in a hot second for someone looking for great game design and some posh silent-world-building. If you're looking for one of the better remakes of beloved 90's games or even the best Tomb Raider game, I'd say look no further. Tomb Raider: Anniversary is definitely worth your money. I'm giving it a 7/10.

Posted: November 22, 2016
												Now this is how a good remake is made. Tomb Raider Anniversary perfectly blends the original Tomb Raider game with the Tomb Raider Legend engine. It's not exactly a remake, but more like a sequel to Legend with the original game environments. And like Legend, the game is good to play. There's tombs, exploration, puzzles to solve, and decent combat. The major drawback from Legend for me was that the environments are plain. There's detail, but the game overall lacks color and liveness. And the PC version doesn't have the next generation graphics from Legend, making it look even worse. But i have to praise the increased longevity, because this game is almost twice as long as Legend. So, this is a game for everyone who likes adventure games and the Tomb Raider franchise, especially if you want to relive the original in a modern engine that works pretty nice, or want more stuff like Legend.

And since a patch for the game can't be expected anymore, I absolutely cannot recommend Tomb Raider Anniversary.

Posted: March 11, 2015
I trust my instincts.Lara is back in a brand new adventure that takes you all over the globe as you search for pieces of the long lost artifact known as the Scion.Gameplay+ Very fun puzzles+ Fun traversal/climbing+ Well thought out environments, puzzles, and traps+ Water puzzles and traversal done very well- Camera problems often cause frustration and failure on jumps/puzzles- Glitches can often kill you or send you back to the beginning of the puzzle- Combat can be frustrating, if not menial and boring (hold right click and spam left) The gameplay in Tomb Raider: Anniversary is much like the older games. It's a well-polished, easy to learn game. Filled with amazing puzzles, beautiful locations, and just a feeling of adventure throughout the whole thing as you go to several locations throughout the world. Well thought out and very fun, especially if you are a fan of the earlier games. However there are a lot of camera problems and glitches that can cause you to die, or simply making you start the climb or puzzle again, which can be very frustrating and often times made me close the game and come back later. And combat I found boring quite often, it was simply hold right click to lock target, and mash left click while just using space/shift to jump and dodge around, but they had a variety of enemies which were nice. ( Dinosaurs!)But it was worth it to me as I enjoyed every other aspect of the game thoroughly.Graphics+ Beautiful graphics for its time+ Gorgeous environments (including outdoors and temples)+ Great variety in locations- Graphical glitches- Sometimes gamebreakingThe graphics in this game were quite beautiful for its time. Obviously compared to graphics on new games they are not up to par, but the beauty of this game outlives time. It is still amazing to look at as each environment is good looking, polished, and clearly had effort put into it. There is a nice variety so nothing looked just the same as the last area you went into and you really felt like you were in different parts of the world. There were, however, some graphical glitches that were sometimes gamebreaking or at the very least required you to restart from a previous save and lose progress. Frustrating at times, but not so many that it makes the game unplayable in any chapter.Story+ Interesting story+ Good dialogue+ Great info about Myths and Gods The story of Anniversary was much like the older Tomb Raider games. Find a piece of an artifact, someone takes it, go get it back while finding other pieces of the artifact. The story was interesting, and the dialogue was well executed and kept me interested most of the time. In addition to the main story Lara would often talk about myths, legends, Gods, and just locations you visit in general. I personally like history and myths, so it was very entertaining for me to hear about certain temples and Gods (such as Anubis, Horus, Poseidon, and more) as I went further into tombs.Overall/Quick Review+ Great puzzles+ Beautiful locations+ Interesting story- Frustrating graphical issues and glitches Beautiful graphics, well executed puzzles, and amazing gameplay. Well-polished, challenging, and rewarding through it all. Combat is boring at times, although the enemies are varied and entertaining, and some graphical glitches and camera issues can make the game more frustrating and downright infuriating than fun at times. If you loved the old Tomb Raider games you will love this one just the same.I do highly recommend this game to all players, fans of the series or just starting off, as it takes you on a whole new action survival adventure to beautiful and exotic places around the globe with the amazing Lara Croft.

Posted: July 22, 2015
												Very good.The levels are very well designed, both in terms of visuals, and in terms of gameplay.  The ancient temples and ruins have a great atmosphere of abandoned isolation (broken slightly by random medikits and weapon ammo lying around in them), though like in the original the final area's change of theme and pace is a bit disappointing.The puzzles are the good kind, where you can either work out the solution fairly quickly, or find yourself stumped for a while only to see the answer and then wonder why you didn't see it earlier.It's been nearly two decades since I played the original, so I don't remember it as well as I might, but this remake captures the theme and style that I remember, while adding much more detail and fluidity.On the flip-side, the controls and camera are evil and conspire to kill you as often as possible.  Most of your deaths will be because of them, rather than actual mistakes.  The camera is uncooperative and often forces you to make blind leaps of faith because it won't let you look at where you want to jump to - such as hanging from a ledge, but being unable to look behind you because the camera refuses to go near the wall in front of you.While using the new grappling hook in most cases is relatively straightforward, using it to run along a wall and then jump sideways away from the wall is the single hardest thing in the entire game, and Lara will constantly jump the wrong way and fall to her death.Combat relies heavily on quick-time events rather than bullet-sponge enemies like the original did.  Interactions with human enemies is entirely quick-time events, and all enemies can be "enraged" by repeatedly shooting them, which makes them charge at you and offers a quick-time event to score a critical hit on them, which works against all enemies but is required for the bosses.While I do think that the slightly more puzzle-oriented bosses fit better in the game than bullet sponges, I would have preferred if these timed events for combat and bosses were more fluid, happening in real time with a slightly larger window, rather than having the game slow down and show instructions on your screen at the appropriate times.  That would have made finding out exactly how to beat the enemies a little more of a puzzle and less of a timing challenge.Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone who likes exploration ancient ruins, solving puzzles, and navigating platforms and complex terrain.

Posted: January 4
												Tomb Raider: Anniversary is the second game created by Crystal Dynamics in the first reboot of the franchise. The story of TR:A takes place before TR:Legend, but is a remake of the original Tomb Raider game that came out in 1996.The story starts off with Lara staying in India, when sheis contacted by Jacqueline Natla, who knows the location of the Scion, an artifact that Lara and her father has been looking for. She travels to Peru to find the Scion, and when she finally acquires it, she found out that there is three pieces in total. It also turned out that Natla had hired other archeologists to find the other pieces, which starts a hunt to find the other pieces before Natla gets them.The gameplay is much like how the other Tomb Raider games work; you move around to go through puzzles by jumping, climbing and sometimes shooting things to go further into the levels and find treasures and relics. What is new in this game which wasnt in the original, is Lara can jump on poles and use a grappling hook. Certain other quirks has been improved and you can also toggle wether you want to manually grab to ledges (holding shift down when you jump to gab an edge).Seeing as this game is actually a remake of the original game, much of the puzzles and level designs are the same as the original, however with a much better graphical outlook and many of the levels are much more open and, in some cases, a bit better in design. All of the levels are close to true to the original designs, so if you have played the original game, you'd recognize the levels fairly easy, including the different encounter with mobs, bosses and so on.A new addition is also the "adrenaline" where Lara can dodge an incoming attack where the game slows down and a target appears which in the end turn red and you can instantly kill that mob.Following the tradition of the old TR games, including the classic game, the "Croft Manor" is open for exploration! However it has much more than what the original had, which was just practicing jumps, grabbing and such things. In TR:A they have similar things, but also puzzles you can solve to gather items and even unlocking the bedroom where you can change Lara's outfit into one of the unlocked outfits. One of them is even the model from the classic game. :PThe graphics of the game is, in my opinion, much better than TR: Legend, whose graphics were at times okay, but there was many glitches and problems with it when I played it, while most of the shadows and other graphicals effects were baked in this game. They also upped the animations on Lara, giving her a much more expressive face, but a somewhat caricatural design on Natla and some of the other antagonists.The game was very very hard. It stays true to its source, though, which is good. The game is sort of merciful by giving you auto-grab amongst other things, while the original had none of it and the graphics and textures didnt make it any easier. Either way, Anniversary definitely deserves a lot more attention than it got. It can be frustrating, but it is what is fun about the game; when you finally succeed then it feels good. However, I found out that there were was a certain relic that was impossible for me to get, due to what seems to be a graphical bug (?) so no matter how much I tried, I could never grab the ledge and get it and I did follow a video guide to make sure that I didnt do anything wrong. Otherwise the game is pretty darned good and respect its source pretty darned well, while still adding new content to it that doesn't feel misplaced.PROS+ hard and challenging puzzles+ decent graphics+ fun boss battles+ good replayability (time trial, unlockable outfits etc.)CONS- some issues with graphics/mechanics can make certain mechanics and parts of the game unplayable- death can be a bit too punishing due to checkpoint saves (especially during some of the longer and harder puzzles)- camera is a bit wonky

Posted: August 12, 2015
												This anniversary version of the original Tomb Raider feels just like the one most used to play as a kid, expect this time around the graphics are updated as of 2007 (and still looks pretty good) and Lara has couple of new tricks up her sleeve, If you remember getting frustrated at the controls back in the days and having a tough time solving some obscure puzzles, then ya dont need to be disappointed: it's all still there! Anyway, this game has an nice old school adventure game vibe, and I can recommend it to anybody who used to play the original games years ago, as it's just improved version of the Tomb Raider games for PS1 with better graphics.

Posted: January 3
												The idea of the remake is nice, and I was looking forward to pass places I visited some time few years ago in the old games, now in better graphics quality.It's never good if you can feel if a game is a port from another platform, which happens in this game. The controls and the camera don't feel good at all. With my NVidia GTX 970, the camera appears to be jerky, and that is very annoying. Activating V-Sync luckily reduces the effect.The most irritating thing about the game is in my opinion the manual save function. Either it is a bug or it is intended that you can only save the game at certain places in the game (after completing a sub-level). Additionally the game saves 'checkpoints' automatically at some more points while passing by. If you die, you spawn there again. But if you reload the game, you spawn at the last manual save. So if you are standing, for example, before a difficult leap (which doesn't happen rarely in Tomb Raider), you cannot save before you jump. So if you die, you will be at a checkpoint again and maybe need to climb/run a large distance again, and if you don't die, do the same or worse. And reloading from the last save brings you even farther away from your last position.The manual save issue is especially annoying, when you reach a point where you have to decide which path to go but still want to leave the other paths open to not missing something (e.g. artifacts). Sometimes it is not clear beforehand, when a path can't be gone back and then there's often an automatic checkpoint after you went through a one-way path. So you can't either go back through the path nor load your last savegame (if you don't want to be 5km far away again) if you notice you may have gone the wrong way (or just want to check the other ways).

Posted: January 8, 2015
												So I skipped Angel Of Darkness and dove right into this one. And boy did it deliver. I can tell because they retained that awesome fun of boss fights and the feeling of adventuring and discovery. In this remake it's not quite the same though, but fun none the less. Previusly you had to shoot and jump around to avoid being hit. This time you will need to try shooting it in the weak spot. Surprisingly bosses don't do as much damage as some of other enemies.And some enemies can be really annoying because they will knock you around even though you can dodge and recover after being hit it will not work if there are 3 of them at the same time.This being remake and some puzzles are different because some game mechanics changed a bit. There are new things in the game too. Like grapling hook. Which is nice and enables some cool puzzles to be solved. But you need your timing to be on point or you may end up jumping the wrong way.As always there's a lot of hidden areas and this time by collecting artifacts and relics you can unlock outfits, art, music, etc. I didn't collect them all though. If that would unlock some achievements I'd try harder :)Overall it felt familiar even though I played the original 3 years ago. It looks great, it plays great. So if you consider playing older games in the series before going for newer ones or even the other way around pick this game up. If I had a change I'd buy it on PS3 because you get achievements there.Totally recommend.

Posted: January 21
												Tomb Raider Anniversary successfully captures the look and feel of the original while improving upon the controls, camera, and overall design. Anniversary is definitely more about isolation and exploration which is a welcome change from the later games in the series. While not perfect in every aspect, its flaws can be easily overlooked since the game is really fun. At the lower price point, I was expecting a smaller, less polished game but I am glad to say I was mistaken. The developers have really made something special.I decided to try out Anniversary because it was a remake of the original, which I so fondly remember as being a very atmospheric game. Anniversary captures that atmosphere very well with its beautiful graphics, detailed level design and excellent sound-track. The characters' facial expressions during the cut-scenes are also worth mentioning as they are brilliantly done. Sadly, the combat system is very poor. It's hard to learn and particularly frustrating at the best of times. Lara has a bad habit of auto-targeting the wrong enemies at the wrong time (and sometimes she targets shootable buttons on the walls in favour of the vicious beasts that are busy tearing her up). Thankfully, this game is sparsely populated with enemies and, most of the time, you'll find yourself enjoying the exploration and puzzle-solving aspect of the game, which made the original such a winner.
